description:
I should add two things:

- I've bought that cake several more times, even once as a quarter-sheet cake for a big birthday party. I love that cake 

- We buy Challah there just about every Friday now. I just feel like it is the best balance between crust and soft insides, with a taste that's just a hair's-breadth away from being sweet. I don't know how else to describe a challah that's perfect. It feels like Home.
author: Brent D.

description:
Went to this location today as I commonly do multiple times a week, and was surprised by a interestingly rude reception. 

My intent was to order my normal chicken empanada though I was to visit my parents whom live in Noe Valley,  thus I tried to order 8. Joe's comment regarding the number I was requesting was: "What am I going to sell everyone else the rest of the day", could I just give you six". Really??

Last time I checked I have never gotten a discount for more empanadas so the bakery still makes the same amount of money. How about baking more empanadas, or preparing more unbaked empanadas just in case you sell more? 

Anyways, I've decided to assist Joe with his apparent inventory concerns by moderating my visits to many less if any.
author: Chris L.

description:
Destination baking Company is a cute secluded shop located on the corner of Castro. It's small but stands out! This place has great pastries baked right there in the ovens. I had a blueberry danish and a bran muffin. Both being so yummy! The coffee is really good too! They have these small auger cubes that look like they were hand made. One negative is the abundance of other coffee shops in the same downtown. I think this place could add more to make it unique for sure. Hopefully they last! 

Cheers!
author: Chris K.

description:
I live over an hour away. 
I don't work in that direction. 
I had never even been to Glen Park. 
Someone at SF General told me about the pain au chocolat 
Looking at those words is interesting. 
Pain is a French word for bread, but it is also the English word for a powerful physical or emotional feeling. 
Au is a French word, but it is the symbol on the periodic table for Pure Gold.
You know what chocolat is whether you speak French or not. 
Maybe Destination's version of Pain Au Chocolat is what the very first French baker who ever invented it was intending to make. 
Perhaps that unknown Frenchman spent his whole life trying to perfect it. 
Perhaps that is the "Destination" in Destination Baking: perfection.
author: Gene S.

description: Great chocolate tart and peanut butter cookie! Nice neighborhood, pleasant experience overall. two thumbs up.
author: Katherine M.

description: Fantastic. Croissants are flakey, brilliantly browned, and buttery. Maybe a teeny bit on the oily side, but crispy, flakey, and a worthy indulgence. Fantastic pies and quiche.
author: Barry H.

description: Despite complaints by other reviewers about poor service and crabby owner, I've experienced nothing but kind service and great food. This is my go-to for potluck, holiday and breakfast pies. The two quiche selections - Lorraine and seasonal vegetable are amazing! The pies are eggy and cheesy and baked to perfection. The weekend seasonal fruit pies are also fantastic. I recently ordered a white peach pie that captured the essence of the in-season fruit and not drowned out in sugar. I also love their olallieberry pie when it is available. And the Thanksgiving pies, particularly the sweet potato, apple and mince meat are favorite selections. Perhaps my experience is positive because these are all order ahead items. The owner is always accommodating and the pies are consistently ready at the time requested.
author: Priscilla O.

description:
I'm always excited to try new bakeries, and had the chance to stop by Destination on a Friday afternoon. They weren't busy around 2pm, but they had already sold out of a lot of items, so you'll have to come early if you want to see the full selection. I ended up trying:

-Sticky Bun ($3.75): This was a giant sticky bun, but it was on the doughier/heavier side. I think they also added cardamom or some other strong tasting spice, which I felt ruined the overall taste of the sticky bun. I wouldn't get this again.
-Mazarin (Almond/Raspberry) Tartlet ($2.85) & Apple Streusel Tartlet ($2.75) [https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=10SOO3BYbqk18UDM_XSVOg&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg]: The mazarin was good overall, but the almond and raspberry flavors were very light. The crust was also very hard since I had it straight from the display fridge. This was good, but I'm not sure I would get it again. The apple streusel wasn't very good- the filling was too thin, but the topping was good. I think this would have been better if I re-heated it a bit in the oven first. I probably wouldn't get this again though.
-Carrot Cake ($3.50): Yum- this was my favorite item from this bakery. The cake was moist, and the cream cheese frosting was really good. Recommended!

They also bake homemade fruit pies, but sadly, do not sell them by the slice! I hope that changes at some point. I would come back to try their other items if I was in the area, but would only come if it was earlier in the morning. There isn't much parking right in front of the bakery, but there are some street parking spots a short walking distance away.
author: Amy D.

description: Cute little bakery and coffee shop where you can grab some pastries if you're in the neighborhood. I found it to be just 'fine' - not quite the best of the best - but no complaints either. A nice three star option if you're nearby and want a croissant and a coffee.
author: Sean B.

description:
Destination Baking Company reminded me of something you'd see out of Gilmore Girls. This whole neighborhood is so quaint and cute. 

Walking you instantly see the arrangement of pastries and goods they have available but I think the most alluring thing is the racks of challah, danishes and baguettes they still have cooling off from the oven. 

I got the bearclaw and a baguette only because there's a $5 minimum on card SO BRING CASH. 
Despite this extra purchase, the bearclaw was delicious. The croissant dough was flaky and soft and not too sweet and the almond filling was perfect. The icing drizzle on top add the extra sweetness needed.

The baguette was also amazing. For $2.25 or $2.50 (I don't remember sorry) it was worth it. Soft inside, crunch crust, and basically carb heaven. 

There's some seating available in the store but it's a bit toasty. Overall great place if you're just walking around in the neighborhood.
author: Michael L.

description: The pies here are incredibly good; be sure to order ahead for holidays. for Easter, we get shaker lemon pie, and in the summer, nectarine. So good! Minus one star for the rude owner.
author: Whys W.

description: Wonderful pastries, reasonably priced. Need to go early because they sell out fast. My favorite is the almond cresent.
author: Frances B.

description:
The place itself is small and cute. I got a croissant and a pain au chocolat. The pain au chocolat had brown sugar on top of it, which is very strange. In fact, so strange that I will only review the croissant:

(Almost Snobbish and French) Croissant Review:

- Appearance: 2/5 (it looks kinda sad, don't you think? What an odd shape... This croissant doesn't look very healthy! It needs to work out a bit. Maybe some Vitamin D and a vacation too...)

- Texture: 3/5 (a nice crunch on the outside, but something feels off inside. Basically like talking to your techy friends in SF... Also, not enough layers are present. And it's not flaky enough either. Damn. What a shame. That last bit should be read in Gordon Ramsay's voice...)

- Price: 3/5 (Almost 3 bucks for a croissant? And then they wonder why I voted Bernie...)

- Taste: 2/5 (who thought it would be a good idea to dip the whole croissant in butter after it's done cooking? Because that's the overwhelming taste here... Butter. Not like a subtle hint of it either. More like shoving a spoon of butter in my mouth kind of experience. The croissant can't actually express itself if it's covered in butter. When you go out with friends and decide to put 5 layers of makeup on, you gotta ask yourself: what have I become? Is this really me? Same thing here...)

- Verdict: GUILLOTINE!

I mean, the pastries are not that bad. They're just not that good either! Green tea was pretty good, though...
author: Nathan H.

description: Came here while waiting for my wife. Small bakery on corner. Wasn't sure what to order had a few selections that were pleasing to the eye. Left with coffee cake and carrot cake. Thanks cakes were awesome.
author: Sherri R.

description:
Rude lady working here takes a long time to help customers, and has a snobby attitude. Seems to treat customers very differently based on race after watching a few interactions. 

Baked goods selection very skimpy; just a few stale looking items on display. Tried some  items and they were very mediocre. Avoid this sub-par bakery, you can do much better across the street at the market.
author: Yelp R.

description:
This is a cozy neighborhood bakery. Pies are the item they totally knock out of the park. They have a great variety, and even more at Christmas. All the ones I've had - peach, apple, lemon meringue, sweet potato, marionberry, pear, banana cream, and chocolate cream pies - I can totally vouch for. The fillings are spectacularly made, and the crust is substantial and flaky, While I know people who leave their pie crust uneaten (yes, they don't just do this to pizza), I love a good pie crust and greatly appreciate how this bakery doesn't let its fillings smother the crust. 

Their regular pies were around $18 last year, and it is an amazing steal.  Some pies at Marie Callenders or Whole Foods cost the same, if not more, while these are the pies that will be a hit at a holiday gathering. They even have mince pie here. Yep, you heard that right. 

Some other items that are pretty good are the galettes, flatbreads, and moon pies. Most people get their goods to-go because it is a bit cramped in this shop, and the lady that I always encounter at the register is lovely and fast with the coffee.
author: Alice L.

description:
Had some time to kill in the neighborhood. Found this place on a fluke.

Pros: 

Prices are good
Great variety 
Everything tasted fresh
Something for everyone: cupcakes for kids and tarts for adults
Accepts credit cards 

Cons: 

Tiny inside
Limited parking
Not the friendliest 

Hidden excursion. If you're local I'd check it out.
author: Rosalyn W.

description:
I have been a neighbor and loyal customer of the bakery.  The shop is one block from my house.  Recently I have had issues with my health and I asked if a staff member could send up a cappuccino.  The owner was very rude and "said we are not a delivery service.  
However, the owner has no problem taking my money for over 12 years with a cost of a cappuccino for $3.  I have never received a free bakery item.
The rest of staff are friendly and food pretty good but greasy.
author: Jocelyn K.

description: Hands down, some of the best pastries in San Francisco. You can tell you're getting something hand-made when you take your first bite! The bear claw and nut roll are heaven.
author: Jeanine C.

description: This place sucks they keep erasing my reviews because the owner is a grumpy old men and his croissants are weird looking they are not flakey like other croissants that i have tasted and made
author: Gregory H.

description:
Who doesn't love the neighborhood bakery?

And when you live in an adorable little neighborhood like Glen Park, you have to have a good bakery.

Located on Chenery a block up hill from "downtown Glen Park," this bakery has a small store front featuring a display case, register, and two sitting areas, while the rest is the bakery itself. You will almost always see someone preparing some baked good in the back.

The displace case items change daily and based on availability but usually have: cookies, danish, apple strudel, croissants, tarts, and various other pastries. Oh and of course coffee, because Glen Park can't get enough coffee.

You can special order a variety of things including challah, pies (both savory and sweet), custom pastries. Not sure about cakes, but would have to ask.

While they close at 6:30 so have to rush a bit off Bart, but at least once a week I'll try to swing by, grab a cookie for dessert, maybe a pastry for the next day. I will always buy their black forest ham and gruyere croissant because it is amazing.

So if you need a challah or something special during the holidays and in the area, I highly recommend this place. Got a challah for Rosh Hashanah here and it was good.

Note: there is an advantage to going later - the few remaining items will usually be on BOGO.
author: Michael C.

description: You could easily drive right by this bakery and hardly notice. Really lovely space. There weren't a zillion things to choose from at 4pm, but I'm betting all their versions of each item are stellar. I'm often suspect of a place with too many items on offer and assume some or many might be just average.  I had a brownie and with out exaggeration it was the best I've ever enjoyed. Friendly staff too-the guy actually asked me if I had a preference and I told him any would do fine.  I just love stumbling on my new favorite place!
author: M M.

description:
After a long time I tried again - things change, the shop is one block from my house and the idea to get fresh croissants on a Sunday morning sounds exciting. 

So... my daughter: "not the worst croissant I had, too greasy, the frozen home baked are better.  

Both the almond croissant and the pain au chocolat were very mediocre and had only had faint resemblance to the real thing. The bakeware at Starbucks is better.  

Maybe they can hire someone who knows how to do the job? Croissants are difficult to make but not impossible.  

Not a destination. Not even 1 block. 

Btw. The baguette at Canyon Market is amazing.  Sells fast.  Go early.  And that is worth a detour
author: Flo B.

description: Love this place. If I could, I would give it 6 stars.  My favorite are the blueberry and cherry danishes, but I've been coming here for years and also love their cookies and small tarts. Everything is delicious.  Whenever I am in the vicinity I go out of my way to make it up the little hill to get here. Highly recommend!
author: Martha T.

description: Great bakers!  The scones & Danish are delicious.  Ordered a pie for thanksgiving that was enjoyed by all.  Love these folks & their culinary artistry.  A Glen Park gem.
author: kate l.

description:
I stopped by here on a Wednesday morning around 7AM. There was only one other customer in front of me, so service was quick and attentive. The woman who helped me is the sweetest. She's the typical kind of grandma that loves to bake for her grandchildren.

So about the baked goods, I bought a cherry danish, the cheddar scallion scone, and cinnamon bun for a little under $10.

Cheddar scallion scone: Yum! I could taste the cheddar, but not the scallion. It was good. Would order again.
Raisin Cinnamon Bun: the frosting is so delicious, sweet with this kind of light texture to it? They're generous with the frosting even if it doesn't look like it(my initial visual impressions) but as I continue to eat it, it's the right amount. What I'm a little disappointed about is the amount of cinnamon. It's there, but a bit light. I love cinnamon and it's a cinnamon bun so I wish the taste was stronger.

Sorry, I didn't get to try the cherry danish so no review.

Great neighborhood bakery. Would recommend going in for morning yumminess.
author: Mimi T.

description:
We bought 4 items to try at this bakery.  It's not the worse I've ever had but not the best.
1. Cranberry scone - it was too dry for me, not than many cranberries.  The outer crust had a nice crunch. Wouldn't buy again.
2. Sticky bun - way too many nuts. Most places have either pecan or walnut, this was topped with a lot of almond slivers out numbering the walnuts. The sticky sauce was not gooey enough and the bun wasn't that moist, between the 3 pastries, it was the only one I'd buy again. 
3. Cinnamon bun with raisins - a decent amount of what looked like Thompson raisins, Bun was too dry. We bought the one with the white sugar glaze, there wasn't much glaze compared to what a Cinnabon has. 
Overall, I think you'd fare better with the sticky buns at Devil's Tooth Baking Co. in the Outer Sunset if you really want buns.

We bought a fresh mixed berry tart to take to a friend's house.  
The place is a nice corner shop with a few tables for dine in.  We were looking for pies but they told us the pies were not available until 12:30 PM and only one flavor today - apricot.  I don't like apricot pies so we ended up at a Supermarket and got a small cake instead.
The tart was $24 and was "OK". The crust was cookie-dough like.  I still prefer the tarts from Ambrosia even though it costs a few dollars more.  And, you'd do even better with the mixed berry pies (which are huge and taste much better) from Costco for about $13.
author: Ry T.

description: The baked goods here are as good as they get.  Freshly baked and yummy.  I went to Paris recently and tried the baked goods there, only to be disappointed that they didn't compare favvorably with my neighborhood bakery
author: Byron H.

description: Decent pastries terrible customer service by male owner.  We came home and found two out of 4 pastries upside down in the box.  The box had no excess space and the other 2 pastries were in perfect condition, we were careful w the box driving home so it was clear they were placed accidentally in the box upside down.  When we went back to explain what happened and get the 2 items replaced the owner blamed us for flipping the pastries intentionally which makes no sense whatsoever since we didn't stand to gain anything from doing that and continued to insist it was our fault even after we explained we didn't want a problem, and were even willing to pay for the replacements.  What a jerk! Which seems to be confirmed by other reviews here. No more business from us after many years of patronage.  We like to support friendly places where customers are valued.
author: W C.

description: They have excellent quiches and very good croissant's and scones.  The down side is lack of seating and items being placed in containers that are too small
author: Sheila F.

description:
What a surprise.

Dropped in here on the way to BART.

First, this places smells delish!!

Had the bacon quiche and a large coffee.

The quiche is fluffy, savory and moist. You can get it reheated two ways: microwave or baked in 7 minutes. I had it baked and it was Yum-ola !! $4.75 is worth.

The coffee was strong, dark with a clean finish.

Customer service: fine

Parking: ok, if tight.
author: Bert K.

description:
I have been enjoying the baked goods from this neighborhood bakery for many years and stop by 3 or more times a week for a morning pastry and coffee to go.  I like their croissants and Danish pastries (cheese, cherry, blueberry, apricot).  They have the right amount of flaky, crunchy, buttery texture for my taste.  The fruit fillings are not overly sweet and have a lot of fruit flavor.  I often get a little quiche to take home for a late lunch or dinner.  They are perfect.  The crust is very flaky, the filling is creamy with the right amount of cheese and bacon.  I also like their scones.  For later, I like to take home the dried fruit scones, split them and toast them with a little butter.  Much of the time, they don't make it home, though.  They get nibbled on the way.

They also have fresh baguettes, specialty breads,  seasonal pies, special occasion cakes which should be ordered or reserved.   I like everything I have tried and find the quality very high.


When I need a little push to get going in the morning, I think of the treats waiting for me at this sweet spot on Chenery near Glen Park BART station and it's a great start to the day or a special afternoon break.
author: B.J. W.

description:
This little bakery has been appearing on all my feeds and I finally had to make my way out to try this perfect local bakery!

The woman greeted me at the door with a cheery and humble smile. I ordered a small coffee with a cinnamon butter horn and its the perfect morning combination. 

The coffee is at a medium-dark roast, very subtle and robust in flavor and it blends perfectly with the buttery flaky pastry that reminds you of something homemade. There's a hint of cinnamon that doesn't overpower the pastry and the brown sugar crust on top gives it the perfect crunch to the light flaky bread. The icing on top is a super plus!!

I told myself not to have sweets anymore... and I definitely did not cheat today! Going to surprise family with their pumpkin cheesecake for Thanksgiving :)
author: Linda K.

description: This place smells amazing. Husband enjoyed his chocolate croissant. It took everything in me not to stuff my face.  Definitely would come back when I feel like being a fatgirlonarampage.
author: Justine D.

description:
My heart is breaking updating this review. This is my closest local bakery, and the baked goods are delicious. Baked goods are my favorite food group 

But one woman there is extremely rude about giving me a receipt. I nearly always need receipts for my taxes, and I have never had a business make that difficult for me. I cannot imagine her motivation for being the first. Why foster ill will with your customers? It's happened twice. The first time, I paid with my credit card; so, it didn't matter because at least I had the charge on my cc bill. 

Today, I just got one pastry which is below their $5 threshold for allowing payment with a credit card. So, basically, they wouldn't take my card, and they they wouldn't give me a receipt. In the end she wrote the order and amount on a piece of tissue paper. When I asked her to write the business name, she handed the pen to me to do it. 

I looked it up, and technically, they are not required to provide receipts (see earlier paragraph -- why be rude to your customers?). That said, I real receipt (which can be hand written) needed to also include the form of payment.

It was far and away my most unpleasant human interaction this month. That's not what I go to bakeries for! Next time, I'll just get something yummy at Canyon Market, which is also a local business, and the folks there are nice and provide a receipt when one is needed.
author: Lily S.

description:
After picking up lunch around the corner, we decided to pick up some pastries for a snack

Blueberry Tart and Almond Croissant - we came around 1:30 and the pastries didn't taste fresh.  It was kind of stale and skimpy on the toppings

Their pizzas looked really good but we had already picked up lunch

Friendly staff but I don't think I would come back for the pastries.
author: Linda N.

description:
Hello, Vivian here! I work here on weekends and I obviously won't give an actual review because I may sound biased, but I wanted to address a couple of (bad) reviews. Hopefully things will be cleared up :) Feel free to ask me any other questions, but I guarantee you we pride ourselves with hard work and are passionate about what we do. (5 stars for having an excellent working experience with coworkers and customers)

Q: I see pastries behind the counter but am told there is nothing left to buy. What's up with that??
A: The food that you see on the racks behind the cashier (and occasionally behind the counter because we have no room) have already been reserved way in advance! The reservations range from a week to 48 hrs in advance. If you keep coming into the bakery and never see your favorite pastry, reserving is the way to go!

Q: I've seen the workers grab tips for their own, what an untrustworthy employee! Why should I come here if workers feel entitled?
A: If you see workers grab tips, that tip BELONGS to them. Say if one worker was at the cashier for X hours and then another worker comes in and takes over the cashier. The tip that is already available in the jar should belong to the one that actually worked the cashier! Trust me, we're fair about this.

Q: I called in advance for an item but when I arrived there was none left! Why would you lie to us and waste our time?
A: When someone calls to ask whether or not we have a certain item and we say we have the item, we actually do have it. What probably happened was that the item was sold by the time you arrived (a lot can happen in just a few minutes). We usually have a lot of items stocked but there have been occasions where we run out of pastries (sometimes everyone likes to come in super early all at once and order in bulk!). Again, it's best to reserve, reserve, reserve!

Those are just a few that I wanted to address and this is through MY experience only. I hoped that helped! Everyone is entitled to their own opinion.

Tip: If you happen to bring your dog, we do give out dog treats :)
author: Vivian H.

description:
Wake up and smell this bakery! The freshly baked goods just lure you in. You can smell this place from a block away. All the pastries look and smell so good.

I came here craving a ham and cheese croissant. Unfortunately, they were all gone. Instead, I ordered a chicken empanada and also a mixed nut cinnamon roll. Both were mouth watering delicious. The chicken empanada had a buttery flaky crust with chicken (obviously), corn, and potato stuffing. You can have it warmed up by either in the oven for 7 mins or microwaved for 1 min. It's worth the wait.

The mixed nut cinnamon roll is Yummy! It's not overloaded with nuts and not overly sweet. I will be returning in hunt for the ham and cheese croissant and other enticing pastries.

Also, they accept credit cards with a $5 purchase.
author: Annie V.

description:
I had a delicious slice of Italian Sponge Cake today. It was a little over-baked, but still delicious, with chunks of fresh pear and apple baked inside.

Also loved their signature Cheese Danish. Beautiful, buttery pastry surrounding their orange-infused cheese filling. Yummy with a cup of their coffee.

Later in the week, we needed a birthday cake. The friendly gal at the bakery recommended their chocolate cake. It was ready the next day. OH. MY. GOD. It was a wonderful, fudgy, dense dark-chocolate beauty of a cake! One of the best I've ever had.
author: Cathy W.

description:
I ordered a King Cake for my boss's birthday, which landed on Mardi Gras this year.  I looked around for one for a while and had a hard time finding a bakery that made one.  I found that Noe Valley Bakery makes one (that is about half the size and half the price) but it is non-traditional. Even though it sounded great (chocolate-almond filling with an orange glaze) I wanted something typical of New Orleans cakes since my boss went to school in NoLa.  Destination's King Cake was $30 and made about 16 generous slices.  I cut a couple of them larger than others but if I had been more uniform and modest in my portions, it would have easily cut 18 or even 20 slices.  The cake was perfectly fresh and delicious.  The cream cheese filling and brioche dough make it taste like a big Danish - yum.  They insert the little plastic baby after baking, as a safety precaution, and everybody digging in, hoping to get the special slice was a big hit in my office.   

If ever I need another Gallette de Roi, I will definitely order from Destination.
author: Emma H.

description: Only ordered some pastries to-go, so not sure how their wifi and table seating might be. The tarts and cakes are yummy! It's a nice neighborhood place. Great if you want to make a pitstop before checking out the garage sales or open houses in the area.
author: Josephine C.

description: I know from Challah, and this is among the best IN CALIFORNIA including BKLY, LA and other pretenders to the loaf
author: Larry B.

description: I've been here a couple of times while waiting for my bus. Never been dissapointed on their pastries. But last night I was in heaven with their bread pudding. Large piece and it was moist and not too sweet. Just perfect. I will definitely stop by before going to work and buy some more.  Give this place a try. Support your local independent business in your hoods!
author: Hum V.

description:
Hamantaschen!

Hot Cross Buns!

King Cakes!

The morning pastries are wonderful, so tasty and delicious. The cookies are always great, and the variety is always changing. 

It's tucked away in Glen Park at Chenery @ Castro, small, limited seating in and out, and there's always something to savor.

Enjoy!
author: William M.

description:
Was craving a ham and cheese croissant so I did a Yelp search and found this place.
Arrived around 7:30am on Sunday and first thought "uh-oh, they are out" but they were baking away and bringing fresh yummies out right from the oven.
My wife and I loved the croissant, my son would not eat his as there might have been mustard in it (??) not sure why there would be but I did taste it a little bit too.
Still.... good stuff!
author: Joe T.

description: The only thing worth getting at destinations bakery is the pies!  The other baked items are just simply okay. I still can't get over the rudeness of the owner as well as the people that he ultimately hires as the front staff as well. There was an instance when I called to reserve a pie ahead of time and got there to find out that I had misplaced my wallet. I let them know that I would be back shortly and when I came back 30 minutes later, the owner himself said that he'd given away my pie. I seriously thought that he was joking and pulling a prank on me... But he looked at me as if I was the one in the wrong and proceeded to not apologize or you and feel remorse that the situation had happened. By this time of course all the pies were sold out... And it was only 2 PM in the afternoon. So this was a classic Seinfeld situation where he reserve the pie but he did not hold the pie... Anyway their customer service is awful and the owner ultimately hires people that are awful in terms of customer service as well. It's such a bummer because it is nice to have a great bakery in the neighborhood. But again these guys are only good for their pies.
author: Noe V.

description: Destination Bakery has some of the best pastries in SF! The croissants are buttery and melt in your mouth! The cinnamon bun comes with an amazing frosting on top! Love the fruit danishes & butter horns! Joe's a baking magician! Been coming here for years!
author: Alison Finnegan E.

description: If you are in the area do not miss this bakery! I enjoyed an almond bear claw and a coffee in the bay window. You'll immediately feel right at home thanks to the friendly service. I wish I could start every morning here.
author: Kathryn S.

description: I was just there and the staff was extremely rude. It says that they close at 4pm.  I got there with 5 minutes to spare and they turned me away in a very rude manner.  All I needed was to pick up a pie which would have taken less than 5 minutes.  It doesn't matter how good your product is...if your staff is rude... it leaves a bad taste in your mouth.
author: Jeannine M.

description: Got a chocolate croissant earlier today. It was good! I ordered it to go originally and wanted it warmed but the kind lady informed me that it's gonna be a little soft and squishy if I did that so i decided to have it in the bakery. Inside there are 3 tables and some seats. It's a small place so you may not always get a spot. The chocolate croissant was flaky and soft. Warming the croissant = chocolatey goodness inside. It's a slight tad oily but that's quite normal for croissants anyhow. At $2.85, it is definitely value for $ considering many other places sell it for $3.50 and up. There are other goodies on display. They all looked good. I'll definitely be back soon! Parking is pretty easy around the area.
author: Erica Y.

description: Easily worth 5 stars! The workers were super nice and helpful. The food was delicious too! I got a raisin bagel and was extremely pleased with my purchase.
author: Jordan C.

description:
My organization threw a community Mardi Gras party this year, and Destination Bakery made us the most wonderful king cakes. For weeks I couldn't find a bakery in the Bay Area who would make king cake before Fat Tuesday, and was looking into spending hundreds of dollars shipping king cake from Louisiana, but Destination saved the day. Five cakes fed 70 people and we even had some leftover. $30 a cake was a steal for the size and quality of the cakes, and considering they did a special batch just for us. 
Thank you for delicious, cream cheese-filled, fluffy king cake, Destination! We will absolutely be using them again in the future!
author: Katie B.

description: Delicioso! I had the Blueberry Danish and some Sunset South African tea. Very nice location, peaceful, and the staff was very nice. Will be back!
author: Marisol S.

description:
Well... I had the lemon curd tartlet which I quickly consumed. Then I had bread pudding to go. 

I came back an hour later for banana cream tartlet!

They carry other non-dessert baked goods too--baguettes, etc.

You've got me hook, line and sinker!

Prices= moderate. Spend wisely. 
 
Cakes, they make them but they're not on display. So just ask.
author: Fannie S.

description: This bakery has amazing pastries at awesome prices! It's a cute little joint on the corner of Castro & Chenery and the perfect place for a coffee & croissant. There isn't much seating, so if it's busy be prepared to take your food to go.
author: Kearstin K.

description: Pastries are perfectly buttery and flaky!  Their take on an empanada was very different, and scrumptious!  I personally love the espresso as well.  The employees are very nice and friendly.  Not a lot of seats, but it's nice and cozy. :)  This place is such a gem, and so close to beautiful hiking!
author: Kelly G.

description:
A fairly small operation of a bakery with a tiny seating section in the Glen Park neighborhood.  I stopped by here to pick up some breakfast items for my coworkers.  Surprisingly, they had a supply of whoopie pies in the window which I asked for.  They also had cheese twists and a vegetarian and non vegetarian quiche.  I asked for the veggie quiche but later found out that she gave me the non veggie quiche.  My coworker had to fish out all the bacon out of it but otherwise she enjoyed it.  

Since there was only one worker there, I stuck to baked goods despite my hankering for some coffee or a latte.  I didn't feel like I wanted to hold up the line so I just grabbed my goods and skeedaddled out.

 I'm lowering my rating based on the quiche error but otherwise, this is a great bakery  with quality goods.  I wouldn't mind coming back here to try more of their stuff.
author: Ben H L.

description:
I went there about 2 yrs ago.  A heavy set blonde woman was talking to 2 customers.  I wanted some coffee & something sweet.  The bakery clerk kept on carrying a private conversation with the 2 women, who appeared not to be buying anything.  I waited another 5-7 minutes.  She failed to acknowledge me.  I turned & walked away as she was now giggling with her "friends."  There was an older couple eating.  The male looked at the clerk & then over at me,  as I walked out.
 I wondered if my attire made her think I had no $$ ( i was still in my pjs  Or could it be my ethnicity?  I haven't set foot in there, since my 1st & last  experience was an offensive  one.  Too bad!  I live in this neighborhood & support businesses here.  Too bad so sad I don't have a choice of "O" for cutomer service
author: Dee G.

description: II originally went in to Destination Bakery to ask for a donated bake good for our fundraiser for the victims of the 3300 block fire. The owner did not pause, and immediately donated a peach pie. Slices of that pie were the first thing to sell out at the Bake sale portion of the fundraiser at The Bar on Dolores. Every single person who got a slice said it was the best they had ever had. My hubby had a birthday request for pie, and of course I went to Destination Bakery. They only had one pie left that was berry. Okay, let's try that; again it was the best berry pie ever. You can't go wrong at this place, friendly people +  baked goods that will knock your socks off = 5 ++ stars.
author: Lee P.

description:
I had fabulous visits at Destination Bakery. Destination Bakery is terrific choice for a delicious and reasonably priced breakfast, brunch, or lunch. The bakery has a large and varied assortment of both delicious savory and sweet baked goods. The bakery is a fun, local, neighborhood bakery walking distance from Glen Park BART station.  The bakery has a wonderful "neighborhood bakery" atmosphere - distinctive, unique, friendly, and quite a bit of character. Each time I got baked goods at the bakery, the staff was attentive and provided excellent customer service. 

I have been there several times before, and this time it was exceptional! I had a slice of vegetable mini quiche.  The quiche was amazing. The crust was flaky and light, not gummy and wet. The filling was eggy, not heavy, with a wonderful leek flavor bursting through the quiche. The ratio of crust to quiche filling was just right. Also, I had a bottle of pear juice that was a wonderful compliment to the mini quiche. 

The most wonderful memorable part of my experience at this bakery today was that Michelle, the person who served me, was dedicated in making sure my quiche was heated promptly to just the right temperature that the quiche flavors were highlighted, without being too hot, not cold, and no burnt edges. Furthermore, Michelle made sure my bottle of pear juice was well chilled when I received it. Fantastic!
author: Christina T.

description:
I hate doing this because they're a good neighborhood business with very friendly staff, but I've been stopping in less and less lately.  I really want to give them a good review but simply can't. They're really just ok. Some things are good and others...aren't 

The croissants are WAY over buttered, actually all of their pastries are, to the point that they're just plain greasy.  I love croissants...and cooking with butter... unfortunately not these.  If I want good croissants... I go elsewhere.  Seems like the ONLY time I stop in anymore, is if I'm hungover. 

The sweets are...well VERY sweet... to the point where I really can't enjoy eating them. It wasn't always like this.

The quiches and breads are the only thing worth stopping in for. Only problem is... they sell out of certain breads...so have to get there early.
author: Zoran L.

description:
This mom and pop bakery in Glen Park has my all time favorite, insanely buttery croissant in my old hood in San Francisco.  

Made fresh each day, and often selling out early in the morning, the croissants in this family run bakery seem a little lop-sided at times, but they are the ultimate butter bomb.
author: Rachel H.

description:
This is not an area of San Francisco I would have any reason to visit,  but a wrong bus and a missed connection we can all end up new places.   

I found this heavenly bakery on smell alone,  I had a lovely coffee and a spectacular cheese Danish,   Reminiscent of Europe.    

If your not in the area,  it's well worth the detour.
author: Michael D.

description: After walking by this corner shop several times after our week-long stay in the Noe Valley area, we dropped by on a whim the last morning in town.  Thankfully we did!  We ordered a bacon and cheese quiche, chocolate chip and oatmeal raisin cookie, two empanadas and a decadent cinnamon roll to share.  The woman helping us was SO friendly and sweet - and the baked goods were DELICIOUS.  The cinnamon roll was so light and fluffy, not super dense as I a m used to and the quiche was silky smooth.  I had a sliver of the chocolate chip and it was yum as expected, and my friends who had the other items raved as well about how delicious everything was.  It's definitely a small place, with only 3 little tables, but it was a beautiful sunny morning, and we sat outside where two benches are available for you to sit and enjoy your treats.  Oh, and I did actually have a latte as well - everything was outstanding, including the customer service.
author: Nancy T.

description:
Was walking past this cute place in a rush around 3 in the afternoon after having skipped lunch. Looking inside they seemed to have just what I was looking for, a whole selection of freshly baked goods. When I couldn't decide which croissant to order, the ham and gruyere or the chocolate, the cashier informed me they were currently offering a buy 1 get 1 free special, which made my decision much easier to get both!

Both of the croissants were excellent, not too sweet or salty and I had finished both of them before I had reached the bottom of the hill in Glen Park Village. Mission accomplished.
author: Mark Y.

description:
Fantastic little neighborhood bakery. I've had their cinnamon rolls, scones, and cookies. Their chocolate chip cookies and coffee are what keep me coming back!

Great, friendly service makes me happy to walk in the door and give them my business.
author: Sara S.

description:
This place has become one of my new SF weekend habits. I'm partial to the quiche and the pork empanadas. I'm hoping for the day the Kouign Aman becomes one of their staples. Finger crossed. 

Destinations transports me to a different time with it's Saturday-Evening-Postlike  charm and hearty 'what can I get for you doll' from the welcoming staff.
author: Laura T.

description: I stopped by on the way to a luncheon to pick up a few tarts for dessert.  A simple and clean mom and pop bakery with helpful and friendly customer service.  They offer an array of pastries great to have there or to go, and coffee drinks. The tarts I selected were the lemon, raspberry, chocolate, and apple crumb.  The crowd favorite seemed to be the raspberry tart.  I wanted to get the banana cream tart, but as I was getting it to go, the woman said it may not hold up. Prices are moderate, but adds up quick so be selective.  I'd like to try their other pastries and definitely one of the savory empanadas on my next visit.  The bakery is on Chenery Street, but not as central to Diamond Street as the other shops.  If you are driving you can park without a meter or on one of the side streets of Chenery.
author: Nova P.

description: Gluten-free chocolate chip cookies are a favorite of mine. I walk a mile from my house for them! Grateful they offer a gf option.
author: Bree G.

description: I love this place! Hands down the best Pan au chocolat I have had. Ever!  Flakey, chocolatey, buttery and all out pleasure to consume. Then there are the Quiche... which are unbelievable good. Doesn't matter the type.! Make sure to get two because you won't want to share!!   Great place, fantastic bakers and friendly small town feel. I love everything in this bakery!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Great bakery, and I've been a regular for over 20 years.  The goods are all created with great care, skill and pride.   
But I had a weird experience with the owner, trying to order Thanksgiving pies, and their process seemed rigid, ineffectively communicated, and I felt I was treated rudely.   Maybe he's just stressed by the workload, or maybe he should stick to baking and leave someone with better customer skills to operate the front-of-house.   I'll keep going of course, but this year Mission Pie gets my pie order.  And I had no problem placing an order over the phone, paying at the time of pick-up, with a lenient pick-up window.
author: Matt P.

description:
Just wanted to update. I ordered an 8' chocolate cake to take to work for an important event (i.e. new boss's BDay...). At first I thought it was pricey at $48, but considering how indescribably dense, rich, and flavorful it was, and that it fed about 15 colleagues, it was the greatest career investment I ever made. Screw that graduate degree! 
Turns out the frosting -- according to my foodie peeps -- was chocolate grenache, a mixture of chocolate and cream. The experience was like having an orgy with colleagues but without having to see them naked. Conversation stopped,or became monosyllabic, loke moans and mmmm's and grunts. The focus was on decadent pleasure. Everyone was so satisfied, tired, and quiet. 
Joe runs a small business, works long hours, and really does need a full, 48-hour notice.
author: Lotion M.

description:
Props to this cute little family place for having a single gluten free item- and I'm not being sarcastic. Yes, yes, so I burp absurdly loud and get intense stomach cramps when I eat gluten- why don't I just get over it. Someone recently suggested it was a figment of my imagination, because it was a trend. Well, perhaps obesity is a trend, and lactose issues, and gluten issues, because we eat processed insane food. 

But- this cute little bakery makes their fresh goods with real, whole, local ingredients. And, they have a gf chocochip cookie. And it was delicious. And I can start sentences with a conjunction if I want to. 

So thank you, cute stumbled upon neighborhood delicacy in glen park. It made my day.
author: Candace B.

description: Best apple pie I ever tasted. Great crust, not too much, ample & tasty apples... Had to have a 2nd piece.
author: Chris Ellen M.

description:
Eleven years.

Eleven years they've been in business and I'm just discovering them now? I feel like such a late bloomer. Better late than never though, right?

YOU MUST GET THE RED VELVET CUPCAKE. REPEAT. GET THE RED VELVET CUPCAKE. 

Why? Simply put, it has just the right amount of everything. The red cake is fluffy and moist. The cream cheese frosting is not overly decadent, but melts in your mouth. The two key ingredients complement one another perfectly. My only regret was buying just one cupcake.
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/c2s4NY6M7NuD6FOWDa7YCw?userid=Rp8hHh-2U8Nh-7FhhspVxQ

Bottom line:
Destination will be seeing more of my family and I in 2012. I can't wait to try out the rest of their goodies-  morning bun, bread pudding, tarts, pies, & cakes.

We'll be back.
author: Joy A.

description:
Great staff, delicious pastries. 

Coffee cake, ham and Gruyere croissants, quiche, challah (Fridays), and sticky buns with nuts.  All delicious!
author: Karla R.

description: Love it. Best pies on earth. Try their seasonal shaker pie and my true heart's favorite: Dutch apple.
author: Edissa E.

description:
A most delicious fresh yellow peach pie!  Not too sweet. The fresh peaches were clearly the star! The pie crust was flaky.  Price was right.  $18.

Took advantage of the BOGO for the cheese and scallion scones. Nice flavor but,  a little too light and airy for me.  I prefer scones that are little more dense.

Nice staff.  

Parking is a challenge.  Definitely plan ahead if you're in a rush.

Pies are not made everyday.  They will take a special order,  though.  

Visa & MC accepted.
author: Debbie T.

description: Husband bought carrot cake from a few different places for my birthday- this was hands down the best one!
author: Anastasia J.

description: I have to admit I'm not a big lover of flour. Give me chocolate flourless cake over regular cake and a big pile of fruit instead of a tart. I don't find enough flavor in most of their pastries to balance the amount of dough well. When I do like dough, like in a cinnamon roll or soft hot cross bun, I like it very soft and I haven't found that to be the case here.  However, I recently had an order-in-advance quiche with ham from this bakery that was excellent. Never before have I had two pieces of quiche. Popped it in the oven at home before serving and it was delectable with gooey cheese, nice slices of ham, and a great crust. Is it even fair of me to review a bakery when I don't like flour? ;)
author: Marina N.

description: I just came in today and asked for a glass of water. A man (I'm assuming the owner) started laughing at me  and asked me if I was buying anything, to which I responded no but that I had spent a lot of money in the past at their bakery. I thought he was joking, but he told the cashier not to give me a glass of water. He told me no as well. I hope he realizes that his rudeness and horrible customer service has cost him a customer. Please don't go to this bakery unless you want someone to be rude and obnoxious to you.
author: Kif B.

description:
Wow, talk about time travel.  I last reviewed Destination Baking Company back when I first started Yelping.  That was a long time ago, and this update is long overdue.

Destination Baking Company currently operates a stall at the nearby Glen Park Village Farmers Market on Sunday mornings so I've been enjoying their baked goods even more lately.  The selections change every week so if you're looking for a specific item that isn't featured at the farmers market you can just walk up to the actual bakery a few blocks away.

I've noticed they usually have three to four types of breads, a sweet selection such as their chocolate chip cookies and seasonal baked goods using farm fresh produce.  I've never tried their breads because I'll admit I'm a bit bias in favoring the Acme Breads store at the Ferry Building, but I usually go for Destination's seasonal goods.

Several weeks ago I was floored by the beauty of their Apricot Galette (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/c2s4NY6M7NuD6FOWDa7YCw?select=SZ6m_Ze0zrucrE2q-HtTFA) so I just had to try one (or two).  These aren't as mind numbing gorgeous as the fruit galettes featured at Frog Hollow Farms, but I've got a bit of bias there also that I'll cover in an upcoming review.  For most of this apricot season I've noticed that the little stone fruits aren't quite as sweet as they have been in recent years.  These galettes featured at Destination Baking use apricots from the ApricotKing orchards in Hollister.  The galettes had a good flaky crust with some coarse sugar sprinkled on top.  The quartered apricots swimming in their own juices inside the pastry were quite soft, but as expected the fruit was on the tart side.  In this case the coarse sugar granules on top really helped to tone down the tartness of the fruit.  In my opinion these galettes were very good.

The Gravenstein apple season just opened a mere two weeks ago, and right on cue Destination Baking featured fresh Gravenstein Apple Galettes (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/c2s4NY6M7NuD6FOWDa7YCw?select=2oCu2yRGLxCaNsv3DWGhww) in their farmers market stall this past week.  Similar to the apricot galettes in preparation I found the apples a bit on the soft side, but the fresh flavor of the Gravensteins stood out well.

What won me over in taste however was Destination's Potato Pesto Flatbread (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/c2s4NY6M7NuD6FOWDa7YCw?select=jZoXybEx8Wa_b_9KeSOWow).  These were absolutely incredible after I wrapped them up in foil and baked them back up hot.  The golden flatbread was crispy on the outside and soft and chewy inside like a really good pizza dough.  These are layered on top with a generous spread of pesto, thinly sliced skin-on red potatoes and a mild white cheese.  I bought two at the farmers market, but had I known these were so incredible in taste I would have bought more.

I enjoyed the first one just on its own, then paired the second one with a ragout I created using fresh oyster mushrooms from Far West Fungi, white turnips from County Line Harvest, fresh beans from Dwelley Farms, zucchini, onions and fresh herbs from Smith Family Farms and tomatoes from Frog Hollow Farms.  So darn good that I'm loading up on the Potato Pesto Flatbread the next time I visit Destination Baking.
author: Wilhelm Y.

description:
I respect the whole cute neighborhood bakery thing. If I lived down the street, I would support this place with all my heart. But if you lived anywhere else, this is not a 'destination' to make a trip for.

Everything in the case looks 'meh'. From the flat looking croissants to the pale looking pastries, nothing suggests the promise of flaky french apprentice training, but more immigrant corner mom n pop donut shop sweat equity know-how. Which there is nothing wrong with, if that's your cup of tea.

The whoopie pie had thin crumbly cake like cookies that stick to your hands as you eat it.
author: John H.

description:
I'm sure that this small bakery is a neighborhood favorite and has a lot of regulars (because I heard the owner telling that to his new employee during training) but for non-regulars like me, their pastries, cookies, and coffee aren't anything to come back for.

I was very disappointed with the chocolate chip cookie...it was too sweet, too dry, and tasting very generic. No soul in that cookie at all :(

The Nectarine and Cherry Galette was tart, sweet, and crunchy from the turbinado sugar sprinkled on the crust, but I was very unsatisfied that there was BARELY any fruit in it. That pastry needs to contain about 3 times more fruit filling than it currently does. The crust was really dry too. So not worth $4.50.

I also really wanted to try their Peach Pie, but they only sell entire pies, not individual slices. Noooo.
author: Jessica C.

description: Don't remember much except that I got sick from eating here and the customer service was highly lacking. I will never go back to this bakery.
author: Elle E.

description:
Excellent bakery. Definitely a highlight is that after 2 pm, the morning pastries are "buy one, get one free," which I did not know until it was mentioned to the customer before me. Brilliant.

My favorites were the sticky buns with mixed nuts (such a generous helping of nuts!) and the cinnamon rolls, which I guess tells you I like that dough of theirs. The cinnamon rolls had a nice almost frosting to them which was very vanilla-y. The cherry danish seemed a tiny bit stale and I would have preferred a jammier fruit spread out more. The dried fruit scone (you can choose which dried fruit you want) definitely was not sweet - this was the only one that I tried a little bit of and was not tempted to have any more. I was surprised that I didn't like the sour cream pecan coffee cake too much - it was TOO sweet and gooey for me but maybe would work for others. I liked that there was a no dairy option (Italian coffee cake) but my lactose averse partner has not told me how it is yet.
author: Lisa K.

description: A great place worth a trek up the hill. Sat midday visit to catch up w an old friend.  Crispy almond croissant, iced mocha in a glass, a seat in the sun. Excellent start to the day!
author: Sam F.

description: Best bakery in town. The chocolate tartlet is crazy delicious! Thank you, Destination.
author: Jeffrey B.

description: This little bakery has the best treats!  I've had their coffee cake, which was delicious, but their almond croissants are to die for!!!!!  Never had anything like it and can't wait to go back for another one!!
author: Michelle P.

description: This place is a neighborhood gem.  Unassuming and delicious.  Most things I've tried have been great, but the apple tartlets and quiches are amazing.
author: Marc G.

description:
Destination is a small bakery with a decent variety of offerings for the size. But I would not necessarily recommend it, at least not a trip out of your way, because I'm not a huge fan of the food. When I buy something from a bakery, I want to take a bit and think "darn am I glad I bought this because I could not make this at home." My feeling every time I get something from Destination is "well, I coulda spent that money on the ingredients at Safeway and had four of the same thing in an hour."

Here are my specific complaints. and all of these apply to every trip I've made to Destination: 1- The pastries are drier than I like. In fact, I almost always need a glass of milk or two to wash the pastries down. 2- This may be a factor of timing, but the pastries are never warm. I'm not counting this complaint in my rating. 3- The pastries don't taste like anything super-special. For me, that's a huge deal. A substantial portion of my belly came from cinnamon rolls at a bakery in Vernon Hills, Illinois, and I think that quality of cinnamon role should be a good baseline. Basically, it's a personal failing and character flaw that I expect the world's best of something to be an appropriate baseline.

The reason I ranked this two is that the definition of three stars is "A-ok." The definition of two is "Meh. I've experienced better." And, in that description, Destination is absolutely two stars.
author: David H.

description:
Everything I've tried at this nearby mom and pop's style co-op is yummers, but Destination is my absolute favorite in San Francisco for Chocolate Croissants.  They're so good that I make a special Sunday trip there just to pick up a pair.  Imagine a devilishly generous portion of warm, oozing, top-quality chocolate resting inside a pastry crust that's somehow both flawlessly flaky and decidedly doughy.  Hints of honey and sugar and heaping spoonfuls of time, artistry and love finish off the pastry in fine fashion. 

If but once in life, every San Franciscan should double park and hazard light it up to experience this awesome take on a French classic.
author: Brendan S.

description: Another big hit in this neighborhood of big hits. Excellent baked desserts. The kitchen is open, so you see the bakers in action. Very kind service. Delicious!
author: Frank G.

description: quaint little bakery in glen park, delicious baked good with friendly service
author: Long C.

description:
I no longer live around the neighborhood, but I come back all the time for the bakery here and coffee at Cafe Bello. My favorite is Banana Cream Tart. It seems small, but it is a big burst of fresh banana and sweet cream, with a soft crust that makes the whole thing melt in the mouth. I adore their other fruit tarts too, which is always fresh and juicy. So far, I only had the Red Velvet in term of cupcakes, since I always hated cupcake frosting - but not since I tried it here! The sweetness is just enough and the frosting is soft and goes well with the cake. I also like their crostata and Italian coffee cake.

Since they do buy-one-get-one-free after 2pm, I like to get one croissant to eat immediately, then another for night dessert at home. My favorite is the chocolate. Pop it in the toaster oven and there goes a mouthful of warm chocolate and buttery flakey goodness. 

Coffee is ok for a bakery, but you get free refill. If you are really picky, there's always Cafe Bello just over 2 streets away.

People here are friendly, and I enjoy doing my readings here. Quiet with no distractions other than the smell of fresh pastry goodness...
author: Amy C.

description:
I am in love with this bakery...because they have my favorite pastries AND it's literally a block away from where I live. All the yelpers that recommended the chocolate crossaint were absolute 100% correct. It is DELICIOUS-O-SO GOOD! lol. I'm not even a fan of chocolate, but I totally crammed down two of them in one sitting - yum~ The gentleman that commands the register is really nice. I've tried almost all the danishes and seriously, the texture has just the right amount of crunchiness (is that even a word?) and softness. Also, did you all know the French Bread is ONLY $2.25?!! So do NOT buy french bread at Canyon Market when you can walk one block up Chenery and get it for WAY CHEAPER. In my opinion, DBC has a bit more crunch to their breads compared to Canyon Market.

Oh yes, don't forget...after 2pm danishes and croissants are buy1get1free - that's why today is: TGIF with (not a cherry) a choco croissant ** on top ;)

*If you take the bart...get off of Glen Park (duh) ...walk one block down diamond street toward chenery...then make a right on chenery...walk 1 block up that hill and the first street on your left is DBC~ 

And YES, they take credit cards. It's seriously heavenly so definitely treat yourself to any one of their lovely pastries.
author: Rayne W.

description: Excellent bakery great products and great customer service. Go here!  Amazing treats and outstanding customer service. can't beat it.
author: michael s.

description: Cherry Danish is amazing. The pastries are not exactly inexpensive but they are worth it!
author: David W.

description:
The owner, Joe and the entire Destination Bakery crew were like family to us when we lived on Chenery Street in Glen Park for a few years... and not just because the baked goods were OUT OF THIS WORLD.  It's the friendly type of neighborhood business that you feel great supporting.  But seriously, Joe's stuff is incredible.  I'd put it up against anything.  For breakfast, try a latte and a cinnamon roll.  The chocolate croissants are also spectacular.  The muffins are great... and if you go in the fall, be sure to try the pumpkin muffins.

Get a snickerdoodle cookie or a cheese twist stick for an afternoon snack.  They also have chicken samosas which you can take home and heat up for lunch or dinner (they're my favorite thing in the place).  We also get our thanksgiving pies there - best pies we've ever had.

I can't recommend Joe's bakery enough!
author: Jon M.

description:
I walked into this place for the first time today. The very nice lady behind the counter waited for me to decide what I wanted, then after I paid she gave me a brochure with all the things they make (sandwich bread on Friday's, woohoo!). She introduced me to Joe, the owner/baker of the place. Everyone seemed very nice, but unfortunately I forgot to get the lady's name. 

I got a couple of cookies and a baguette for my first time. The baguette was still warm from the oven! The cookies were not too hard, not too soft...just right!
author: Jennifer P.

description:
I've been here a few times and have never been disappointed. 

Today was a particularly tough day of moving, and I needed some good pastry to keep me going. I bought some fresh croissants, cinnamon rolls, bear claws, and some Gruyere Cheese Sticks. Everything tasted great, and made with lots of BUTTER! 

They were out of Chocolate Chip Walnut cookies, but when they do have them, don't pass them up! They also have lots of tarts and cakes I have yet to try. 

It was so good, that by the time I got from the front door to the car, about 20 feet away. there were grease stains on the paper bag from all the butter that goes in everything.
author: Michael M.

description:
WOooO is so what totally describes this place. I just found this place refered to me by a friend of mine and I'm happy but sad she did. Trying to lose weight this year but this place just change my goals to next year. I got the croissants and its so ridiculous. First of all I got them because when trying a new place my first thought is yelp it! Find out what's popular and what's good..  Finding out people compared these to croisants from Paris Ummm yes please! ill take all versions. great flakey , layered,  fluffy and yes BUTTERY croissant. I hear there hand made from scratch here. No machine but the mixer and strong arms of the little girl in the afternoon. I'm sure that's the flavor of real skills and a genius secret recipe the owner created. I have yet to try everything but the croissants everyone has been reviewing about its on point! THEE BEST CROISSANTS! THEE BEST CROISSANTS. Do I have to type that again? Haha

hows was the service you wonder? Service was very friendly and warm.just like the first vibe i got from this place. The young lady in the morning starts my mornings off to a good start. I get this positive energy thinking hmm she's nice wish there were more people like her around in this world. Actually glen park is a great neighborhood. All the grumps like the guy below who doesn't appreachate friendly service and who obviously like frozen or safeway processed and full of nasty preservatives should move to a different neighborhood. Ill be looking for a place around here just to smell the free warmth and goodies this bakery has to offer. Yummmmmmm! 
Foodnetwork! Discover this place already! Your missin out! 11 years this place has been arpund.. long live destination baking company :HEART: your new #1 FAN
author: M A.

description:
I've tried some other things here, so it's time for an update.  This bakery is one of my favorites.  Certain things here are irresistible.

I like to bring dessert to family get-togethers, just so I can try other offerings.

* Red velvet cupcakes - fairly new item.  I can't compare them to other places because I haven't had red velvet anywhere else.  They're very sweet, smooth, and with cream cheese frosting.  Not so chocolaty, so not on my radar.

* Bread pudding - delicious!

* Carrot cake - pass.  Not a winner for us.

* Empanadas with chicken, corn, and jack cheese - very rich and satisfying!

* Pumpkin walnut muffins - excellent flavor, moist and pumpkinny!

* Corn muffins - okay.  Not a top pick.

* Chocolate and almond croissants - divine, high quality pastries, but too buttery for my husband and me.  We skip these, but know they are very popular.

* Breads - We love the challah and white bread (my son's favorite for toast).  Generally a fan of whole grain bread, Destination's 9-grain isn't our favorite - the grains are too large (my son won't eat it, but will eat most multigrain breads).

Our favorite items are still the:

* Lemon Tartlet - can't be beat - magnificent tangy lemon goodness.

* Mini Chocolate Bundt Cake - made with sour cream, fudgy,  occasionally overbaked, but when perfect, it's heaven!

* Chocolate Chip Cookies - high chocolate chip to cookie ratio and very tasty.

I like that they sell organic grapefruit juice, among other drinks.  This is a very laid-back bakery that really rocks.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
I really miss this place, when I lived in San Francisco, I go there often, when in town. 
There danish are to die for, the mini tarts, especially the banana cream, are so good. I am glad they got the right friendly staff, as the previous ones were, just okay.
author: David c.

description: Wonderful pies and cakes. My son loves the chocolate chip cookies. Cosy atmosphere.
author: Julie L.

description: Slow service and got overcharged. Be conscious of how much your total should be!
author: EJ D.

description: I ordered a King Cake here this week.  It was the better than the ones that were shipped over from New Orleans.  The Cream Cheese in the center was so tasty and made the cake even more moist and yummy.  This bakery also has other delicious items which is what brought me here again.  The have the best Chocolate Croissants and brownies, cookies....etc.....
author: Joan E.

description:
I am that person who leaves all shopping for food and gifts until Christmas Eve.  That's right, Christmas Eve.  Which means I am NOT in a very good mood every December 24th.

I have one food assignment and that is to find my husband mincemeat pie.  After 15 years of searching every Safeway and Lucky's to find the elusive Mrs. Smith's mincemeat pies for our holiday table, I have grown to loathe it.  

This year, something different happened.  I was driving by Glen Park and something made me turn up Chenery.  Something made me find an empty parking spot right in front of a business I had never seen before.  It was called Destination Baking Company.  *cue angels singing*

I stepped inside and the aromas of pastry, cinnamon and sugar wafted over me like olfactory snowfall.  I saw a tray of pies.  I asked, "What kind of pies do you have left today?", never hoping to be so lucky...

Mincemeat.  He said mincemeat.  He pulled out the pie and showed it to me.  Flaky, perfectly baked crust with sugar crystals on top.  Beautiful!  Christmas was saved!

I bought the pie, and 2 chicken empanadas (my husband's other favorite food), and a sugar cookie to soothe my frazzled nerves.

Needless to say, everything was DELICIOUS.  The empanadas were full of meat and vegetables, with a buttery crust, and heated up perfectly in about 10 min in the oven.  But the pie, oh the pie.  Perfect filling, perfect crust.  Such a mincemeat pie has never crossed my path.  It has now gone from a dessert I dread, to one I will crave.

Follow your instincts next time you are near Glen Park and let them lead you to Destination Baking Company.  You won't be sorry!
author: Liz S.

description: Great local bakery! Delicious, simple items at reasonable prices. Pies are around $18 each, - much better than the $35+ many other bakeries are charging. Cupcakes actually taste good and look homemade, as opposed to all the really fancy overly-frosted "art pieces" many bakeries sell (that don't taste good). Really nice employees.
author: Joyce G.

description: Why is it so difficult for me to find you, Destination. We got here around 3 after grabbing some coffee and of course we needed some yummy pastries to complete our run. Unfortunately when we got there they were out of galettes, but I will be back soon to get my paws on them. This review is specifically for the tartlets which are deliciously lovely. Banana Cream being my favorite with fresh bananas and almond. Yum. Light and simple classic but they do it great here. Great place to stop by, friendly staff. Seating fits ~10 people
author: Veronica L.

description:
Great Little Find!

This bakery has seasonal ingredients - which in SF is like, well, totally necessary to even be on my radar.

Every week the menu changes...which means, you'll always get to try something new there if you're up for the challenge of it. OR...you can go for the staple croissant or brownie if you're looking for a classic treat with mouth-watering abilities.

My favorite so far is their personal quiches which are get to take home and pair with a fresh green salad for any meal throughout the day.
Also - they have amazing empanadas and samosas as well which people often overlook when they come in and are mesmerized by the adorable cookies and cupcakes in the case.

I will be coming back here until the guilt of my tummy growing inches and inches starts to get to me.
author: Katy A.

description: Nice neighborhood bakery. They have savory and sweet treats that you can have in their bright storefront. They do the flaky types of pastries really well. I'd totally go back.
author: Theresa D.

description:
I had a mini-birthday party last weekend, and "accidentally" bought too many tartlets for dessert. Oops. 

On the actual day of my birthday, I decided to indulge in the goodies sitting idly in my refrigerator, cause hey, you only turn thirty once.  And besides, it'd be a tragedy to let them go to waste.  

Three tartlets gone in just as many seconds.  The banana cream seriously made me happier than words can even describe.  Try it for yourself, because they really are perfection.
author: Joanne G.

description:
Purchased a dark chocolate cake- moist and not too sweet! $25.00 good deal!
Purchased sticky buns great deal and husband likes it.  Gooey and not too sweet! $3.50 for two due to  happy hour buy 1 get 1 deal 
If it was only cake and sticky buns, it is 4 stars
Purchased the red velvet cup cakes-dry! Very dry! It was a complete opposite of the cake.  I do not know what should I do with the remaining cupcakes...$2.50 each, price is not bad but not worth it.
Maybe it is a hit or miss?
Will try the croissant next time...
author: Susan Q.

description: Hands down the best brownie in the world. Quite a claim, I know, but trust me, I've eaten a lot of brownies in my days. Also check out same reviews from other yelpers. This place is a total gem.
author: J C.

description:
As many other Yelpers have noted, Destination's offerings frequently look and taste stale, leading one to believe that they are holdovers from the previous day. The cupcakes are dry and tasteless. The empanadas are okay, if too greasy. The selection is fairly slim. If you're looking for cuteness in a bakery, or an inviting space to hang out and enjoy a pastry and a latte, you won't find it here.

And their web site -- oh my gosh, their web site. It is a Geocities-style site with misspellings ("your source for quality bakegoods") and seasonal disorientation (after reading about how "Summer is here" on their main page, even though it is March, you can click the upper-right tab to view the Thanksgiving 2014 menu!).

But the real reason for one star is the heavyset female cashier, whose unfriendliness and unprofessionalism have been mentioned in several other reviews. She is truly as rude as an ant in a picnic basket. But ants don't know any better. So she is actually more rude, because she can be held responsible for her behavior.

You will find freshly made, way-tastier baked goods at Canyon Market, just a hop, skip, and a jump away. They use mostly organic ingredients, too (and my money says there isn't a single organic molecule in anything at Destination).
author: Jessica L.

description:
I stopped here one morning and tested out the goods with a croissant. 

It was literally heaven, in my mouth hole.

Convinced my husband to walk here from Noe for a baked treat this Saturday morning, and he devoured 2 bear claws and made sure we got a loaf of sourdough. I tried the almond croissant and it was AMAZING. 

I literally don't think I'll be able to eat croissants from anywhere else ever again. 
I'm ruined forever. In the best way possible. 

I won't even take a star away for the incredibly rude customer who parked her dusty Mercedes blocking two driveways and then cackled at us while we sat on the bench that she had "been doing it for 20 years". 

Yeah you definitely look like you've been going there for 20 years lady. *smirk*
author: Katie D.

description:
TLDR:
- Ordinary stick bun paired with ordinary latte, sort of bland. Consider an extra shot.
author: Christopher L.

description: Yum to the chocolate croissant, blueberry scone, and pretty much just everything.
author: Sonya Z.

description: Wonderful mom and pop bakery! The staff is super friendly, warm and caring and greets you with "Hi sweetie, what can I get for you." This place has the best morning danishes around. I periodically bring some to work to share and everyone raves about how flaky and delicious they are. Their pies are a knock-out! My favorite is the apple crumble top, they only make this during apple season and at the end of the week/weekend, so I recommend you call to reserve one as they always sell out. Their other pies are great- sweet potato and pumpkin I have ordered for Thanksgiving and Christmas and the family loved them. Truly homemade from the filling to the crust! My daughter loves their veggie quiche and will only eat quiche from here. Their pies and morning pastries (I love the cinnamon roll and sticky bun too) are so good that several of my friends who live in the South Bay have taken Bart just to SF to get them for themselves after I have brought them some goodies. So glad to have this charm in my neighborhood!
author: C L.

description:
I've only tried the fruit tartlets but if those are any indication of the quality of the goods here then I'm SOLD. The berries were absolutely fresh, vanilla custard was delicious (you can see the fresh vanilla beans..talk about quality!) and the tart was the perfect ratio of buttery and sweet. It was so satisfying. 

Prices are a little on the high side but like I said, the quality is superb and thus it's worth it. 

This mom and pop bakery is very modest. No fancy decor.. minimalism at its finest. The space is really open; they basically set up a counter and a few small tables and chairs right in the front of the kitchen. I really enjoyed the feel of it though. I wouldn't mind coming back here on a sunny day to chat it up with a friend over a latte and one of their delicious baked goods. :)
author: Helen L.

description: Perfect. I have never had anything here that wasn't utterly wonderful. As far as the reviewer who said their stuff was "overbuttered" -- no. Just no. This is one of the best bakeries on planet Earth.
author: Bruce M.

description:
I went here bright and early one morning after having to move my car for stupid street cleaning. Since I was up anyway I decided to try this place out and went inside to buy some pastries. I walked in and saw many different types of pastries and baked goods but the things that stood out to me was their pecan roll and their sticky buns. I immediately ordered them and went home happy with them fresh and warm in my hands. It was sooo good. The sticky bun was still warm and was just doughy goodness. The pecan roll had mountains of pecans and was amazing. Be prepared when you eat these bad boys, get a napkin ahead of time, you will definitely need it =]

*accepts credit cards but if you don't spend $10 there is a 50 cent fee.*
author: Jayne A.

description:
Butter...*drool*

Destination Bakery is the single reason why I had to move out of the lovely Glen Park Village.  The scent of buttery baked goods used to draw me down the street and tempt me to doughy indulgence.  My most overwhelming weakness was their chicken empenadas.  Words cannot fully describe how wonderful this savory meat pot pie-like pastry perfection is and how extremely happy it makes me to give in to it's power.  The ever so slight crispiness of the outside is complimented well by the inside's warm stewy gravy chicken filling - this combination can comfort you to no end.  

The chocolate croissant , blueberry muffins, and the cheddar-scallion scones are also divine!

Mmm, butter...*drool*
author: Nicole N.

description: Good pastries. Try the pain au chocolate. Yum.
author: Anwar H.

description:
Destination is a warm, neighborhood bakery with great chocolate croissants, occasional homemade breads, and a solid cup of coffee.  As others have noted, their pastries do tend to be on the dry, crumbly side, which is too bad. Still, the service is always warm and friendly, the space is inviting (if very small), and the business is decidedly local. 

When you're in the Village (that's Glen Park, people), be sure to stop by and get a chocolate croissant and a cup of coffee.
author: Julio A.

description:
When the low carb diet was at the height of its popularity, I would waddle into Destination Baking Co & wonder how anyone could give this up. A lack of will power never tasted so good.

Though DBC has a large selection of baked good (forbidden, tempting, luscious baked good), I've only tried a few things:

* DBC sells *the best* chocolate croissant: it has a bubbly, sugary top & flakey, buttery layers surrounding gobs of chocolate in every bite. 
* Marzipan (almond paste) is one of those things I've loved since I was a kid, so my heart does tiny somersaults in my chest when I see it in pastry. DBC's marzipan tart with jam has a dense crust & a gooey sweet raspberry filling.
* They give away day old bread on Mondays for free...I've walked out with nine grain bread & challah loaves which were very soft & delicious. DBC's bread "ages well!" 

I adore all the eateries & shops in Glen Park & DBC is no exception. Friendly staff, ample street parking, cozy neighborhood & after 2pm, breakfast goods are buy 1, get 1 free. Perfect place to reek havoc on your diet, which you can always restart tomorrow.
author: Fancypants X.

description: Our go-to local bakery for birthday cakes! Parking is hard, so it's helpful to bring someone with you to run in.  Nice folks and no unidentifiable ingredients in the food. Just good home style baking - but better!
author: Juna C.
