description: Both sweet and savory pastries are delicious. These guys have also been very accommodating when I have ordered large quantities of pastries in advance for parties. A little pricey, but the cost is in line with the quality. A great asset for the neighborhood.
author: Gaelen X.

description:
I'm giving this place 5 stars, quite simply...because they have VERY good pastries!

It's a small, quaint place, atop Chenery in "no man's land", which is kinda nice actually. You can sit at a bistro table and pretend you are at one of the TINY European cafes ...along with the price tag.

items aren't cheap, but I have to admit, they are worth the price!

My favs:  cherry danish, bread pudding, and mini coconut cream pie

GO! You will be glad you did!
author: Ted K.

description:
Ham and cheese croissants are excellent, as are the chicken empanadas.

edit: Had the fruit cake and panetonne this year and SOOOO DELICIOUS!!!
author: Tommy S.

description: Every Monday morning my husband grabs an espresso at Bello and swings by here to pick up a sweet or savory pastry for me to serve my voice teacher :) so we've been able to try most of their offerings.  They have a light touch, fine balance of flavors, and generally are not too sweet, which I love. Their seasonal mini fruit galettes and tarts are extra-good .  My voice teacher is a hobbyist baker and enjoys everything we've served him from there, the cinnamon bun being one of his favorites.  It's so great to have such a good bakery so close by.  On top of it, the folks there are the nicest, which really helps the digestion. ;)  A local treasure.
author: Cee V.

description: sooooooo good: good people, good food, good vibes, good smells. love their signature tarts. their challah is, in my estimation, the best in the city. their chocolate chip cooks and brownies are outstanding and I've done my research. their special stuff for holidays are incredible. they have an Italian coffee cake with apple sauce to reduce sugar. oh jeez, i could go on...their are simply the best.
author: yelper y.

description:
Although the store is rather small and never have enough seats for customers who really want to hang around, it seems to work perfectly for its style - stay-home moms, dads, retired folks love hanging out for chats, occasionally you will see folks sitting outside, enjoying the sun, sipping their coffee, taking a bite of their scrumptious baked goods while reading the newspaper.  Very relaxing and low-key environment.

I'm not a big fan of super sweet baked goods but I have a weak spot for banana nut bread.  Most of the banana nut bread I'd had were rather dry, crumbly and in room temperature.  Not so at this place.  Their banana nut bread was so moist it literally melts the moment your tongue presses it against the roof of your mouth.  It's so incredibly tasty you want to savor each bite.  I cannot help but smile when I'm done with my last bite, thinking this piece of bread just made my morning!

I had always been a skeptic when it comes to buying coffee at a bakery; don't quite know why.  But I tried their coffee one day when I ran out of coffee at home.  Since I brought my cup, they only charged me a dollar for a big cup of coffee.  Speaking of taste first, it's strong enough for me to taste its freshness (I've been drinking coffee for over 20 years and have been drinking it black for the past 4 or 5).  Not only that, it has enough caffeine to give me a slight jolt!  That's rare.  

All in all, great place!  I hope, when you try their coffee and baked goods, you will have the same feelings.
author: Helen C.

description: Love this bakery! I have coming to Destination Baking Company since it opened 12 years, about the same time I moved into nearby Bernal Heights. The first item we tried was a lemon butter cookie. It was delicious!  It was like a madeline cookie - Soft, buttery, nice lemon zest, natural flavor, & not too sweet.  Great friendly service. Very welcoming. Plus yummy treats!  Whether it's a sweet roll with a latte (great coffee by Montanos Bros) or a big order, they treat you with a big smile. We have tried both their sweet & savory items.  All very delicious. Their special order cakes are devine. Their French & challah breads are the best! The service is excellent!  The young man who works there is so sweet & helpful. The owner is just great! Small place to sit, but quiet & relaxing.  After 2:00pm, all the croissants & sweet rolls are 2 for the price of 1!
author: Pam R.

description: I went for the first time and i felt in love with their hot chocolate.They have really good chicken empanadas and and their  hot chocolate is super delicious.
author: Jazzy L.

description:
Plusses:

The absolute best apricot scone in the US (tastes just like England).
Fresh everything.
Flavor in every bite.
Clean, clean and cleeeeeeeean.

Minuses:

The guy with orange hair on Sundays.  
Lackluster.  Lazy.  Hasn't a clue.
author: Right S.

description:
Worst.  Cupcake.  Ever.  Inedible.  Was in the garbage after the first bite, and I had to keep myself from spitting out the first bite.  And for the price of this awful, dry, tasteless doorstop, I could buy a box of cake mix and make them myself.....and they would taste immeasurably better.  Honestly, how does a bakery make cupcakes this bad?  The taste and texture made me think that it was over 5 days old.  I've made cupcakes many, many times before, and even after 3 days, they were still moist (albeit, not as moist as the day they were baked.)  They keep everything refrigerated, which I appreciate, but that doesn't help the texture of the doorstop.  I mean "cupcake".  I also purchased a banana cream tartlet, a fruit tartlet, an apple streusel tartlet, and two slices of their fruit galette (I can't remember what fruit, specifically.  

The banana tartlet was okay, good banana flavor, but the crust tasted old.  Had a weird aftertaste.  The fruit one (according to my boyfriend) was pretty good.  We haven't tried the galette or apple tartlet yet.....I'm sure the apple one will be his breakfast today.

Overall, I would suggest bypassing DBC, and heading over to Canyon Market for one of their freshly prepared/delivered desserts near the registers.
author: Priscilla D.

description:
I could yelp about the bomb diggity chocolate cookie. Or the delicious French baguette that will set you back just a few bones. Even my Americano was good.

But what you really need to know is the rather nice, slightly surly guy working the counter was rocking this shirt:

http://www.buzzfeed.com/awesomer/two-girls-1-up-cci/buy_the_t-shirt

Anyone who gets it, gets it.

Good cookie. Awesome shirt.
author: Jason B.

description:
Traditional old bakery in Glen Park.   

This is a well established bakery in Glen Park. 
It offers trays of variety pastries and fresh breads daily.
It has an open kitchen, three small round tables and sitting benches by windows for patrons.   

We had the fruity scones, apricots muffins and sticky nuts cinnamon buns so far. They were all very good. We specially liked the sticky nuts cinnamon bun - a cluster of fancy nuts on the bun as the name for it - very very tasty. 
My husband had Italian coffee cakes during one early morning walk to the bakery by himself. He said, it's so delicious, it's soft and has bits of apply in it. 
Almond bear claw is one of my favorite pastries, unfortunately they had been sold out every morning before we got there so it must be everybody's favorite too.

The coffee is a real good deal.
For $1.00 you get a big bowl,- I mean a big bowl -  an honest goodness aromatic smooth rich flavoring coffee; it reminded me of Brazilian coffee when I was in Brazil many many years ago before the invention of instant coffee.
author: Marial L.

description: Everything here is excellent!  Love the chicken empanada's and veggie quiche.  Good coffee drinks and super tasty sweet stuff.  I love my neighborhood bakery!
author: Deb S.

description: This bakery was recommended to me by a friend who lives down the street from it.  I am coming to SF to get married and was trying to get some things arranged ahead of time.  It is going to be a VERY small affair, with just a few close friends.  I called this bakery to order just 3 dozen mini cupcakes.  After the brief conversation I had with Joe, who I was told is the owner, I would not order anything from this place if I was starving to death and it was the last place on the planet to get food!  Joe was the rudest, cockiest business owner I have EVER chosen NOT to do business with.  Sorry Joe, you really lack the needed personality and attitude it takes to get my business.
author: Phyllis W.

description:
Cute neighborhood bakery with the most buttery croissants on the planet (read: not a bad thing). A few tables dot the front, windowed area of the bakery and provide for a nice place to nibble on your croissant, sip your tea, and chat with a friend on a sunny Saturday morning.

4 stars for delicious baked goods and neighborhood atmosphere (when I was there, a woman came in to drop off some Quince she picked off her tree. Doesn't get more neighborhood-y than that!)

Revisit? If I'm ever in Glen Park again!
author: Michael W.

description: This place serves very tasty baked goods.  The problem I have with this small bakery is there is not enough variety and they usually  serve the same items each and every day.  The moon pie is excellent and the sticky bun is very good.  Some of the cashiers could be friendlier in my own opinion.
author: Jerry H.

description:
Their pastries are pretty good but could be better. I tried their hot cross bun, cheese twist and chocolate croissant. All tasted fine but the quality could have been improved.

The chocolate croissant was slightly too soft/mushy inside (too raw); I would have preferred it flakier, more layered and with a greater distribution of chocolate.

The cheese twist had nice flavor but was a little too greasy. The hot cross bun was a little dry but had a refreshing flavor.
author: Elaine L.

description:
Baking is a labor of love when done right, and that spirit is evident in everything they do here. The place is unassuming, tucked away in charming Glen Park, but the output divine.This isn't a trendy cafe trying to look like something vaguely rustic European; this isn't a hipster bakery putting maple-bacon and ginkgo berries in a cupcake; this is just plain-good baking.

They do things in small batches, so don't expect massive quantities, but variety is good for a small place. And unlike many good places in the city, it's not packed and busy - being out in Glen Park has its benefits.

Anything with fruit is particularly good, especially if it looks buttery. That's my rule of thumb here. Today, had a pastry with apples and logan berries, after getting a massage across the street at East-West. The day was forecast to be raining, but it's sunny with patches of clouds; and a cool westerly breeze. Can life get any better than this?
author: Boris C.

description:
I love this place. It's kinda dangerous how easy it is for me to pass it on my way to work in the morning. Yes, the prices are a bit higher for some items than some bakeries but I mean think about it...my favorite item from them...ham and cheese croissants are $3.75 vs some places charging $3 but this has got to be the crunchiest, flakiest ham and cheese croissant I've ever had. And to boot, with real gruyere and black forest ham with a hint of dijon mustard in there. YUM!

I love their scallion cheese scones as well. Yeah, I go the way of the savory. True story.

Service is always friendly and prompt and they take cards too.
author: Steven H.

description:
Their sticky buns (esp. w/ nuts) + choco croissants + citrus tartlets are out of this world. 

Few places are as high quality in every way as this one: ingredients are top notch, freshness is a priority, cleanliness applies to the flavors as well as the place itself, and then there's location. Sticky bun on the way to Glen Park BART? Don't mind if I do! This morning I devoured mine in the two blocks to the station and didn't even have to break the no-food-on-BART rule!
author: Alexis W.

description:
We moved into the neighborhood and started buying Destination's delicious loaves of white bread #1 because it tastes really good & makes a superb vehicle for vanilla french toast, and #2 because the people who work there are just so cool. Also, they have the best pastry icing. Try a delectable cinnamon roll and see for yourself.

UPDATE...we bought a whole berry pie last week and I have been suffering withdrawal symptoms since we ate the last of it. Just the perfect tart berry filling to crust sweetness ratio. And yes, I checked Mission Pie. No berry pies until end of April :\
author: Kerrinski S.

description:
Those pies.. Oh man those pies..
Only one kind a day, and I think it's only on weekends, but you can taste the love. Honestly, I've never had anything else here, but I bet it's good.
author: Mike L.

description: The Danishes are amazing, try the cherry or blueberry
author: Ali G.

description:
I love the sun drenched benches out front and the previously enjoyed newspapers laying around inside. I had the best cinnamon roll ever there. S'what I'm talkin 'bout!! Cinnamon roll with raisins, I don't care if you think raisins are for your grandma. This was fabulous, creamy and light and fresh off the tray, highly recommended. 

Also their empanadas are delectable. Peas, corn and chicken fill them, all of which shine with freshness to make this great comfort food. The guy there asks me if I want it heated in the oven or microwave and serves it on a plate for my relaxing pleasures. Something about the cafe is wonderfully blissful. It's the quiet Chenery Street that always seems to be sunny in the late mornings when I stroll there, and the peripheral baking activity that goes on behind the counter inside. Calm !and breezy!
author: Lyrica T.

description:
The best samosa I've ever had!  The shell was so butter & flaky & there were lots of filling.  The apple pie was excellent too!

So I thought that I found my new cake bakery for my daughter's birthday when they told me that "they're not that kind of bakery!"  I wasn't even looking for anything fancy, just a regular cake w/ some colorful icing & maybe some simple decorations.  1 less star for being so snooty!
author: Jo B.

description: Please, may I have 32 of the yummy chicken empanadas???  And, if you throw in one of the tiny lemon tarts, I'll never be sad again.  Super yummy!  Yummeroonie! Yimmitty-Yum!
author: Allison B.

description:
I finally got to come here the other day. After convincing myself not to go so many times because I wanna be skinny I decided to be the opposite of skinny the other day. Places like this make me wanna throw out my healthy diet out the window, which is why I won't be coming to Glen Park too often! But if you don't care about being skinny or any of that then DO find an excuse to come out here often, maybe even everyday?
From what I saw they had macaroons (which were delicious!!), lots of tarts (of which I tried the raspberry marzipan, also yummm) cookies, pie, cupcakes and etc. Everything looked so pretty and tasty it was so hard to choose. Oh and they also have empanadas!! Everything I bought that day was delicious and I will definitely come here more often then I should.
author: Peeta B.

description:
Lovely local bakery with a couple of nice tables with window seats & 2 small benches outside. Almost everything looks terrific but so far i've only sampled a few items. Hot cross buns (Easter only, I guess) were excellent: moist & packed with fruit & spice. Also highly rated are their super light & fluffy muffins, good, chewy choc chip cookies, & the fruit galettes. They don't seem to make much bread, perhaps it's an early morning offering only. Baguettes are good, more Italian style than French, as fairly dense crumb.
Service is swift & very friendly. I've only tried their espresso, but it is also really good.
author: sarah d.

description:
Searched for this destination per Yelp - thanks!  
Love this type of hole-in-the-wall type of neighborhood shops.  The choc croissant (more choc than some other bakeries!), red velvet cupcake (cake not too sweet, but heavy (weight)  was well balanced w/ the cream cheese ), empanadas and samosa were all pretty good -- I would definitely come here more often when I'm in the area.  Oh yeah, the organic coffee's are good too...plus compl. refill...complemented w/ friendly service by the guy behind the counter.  I need to try all of their baked goods in the future... :)
author: Patty L.

description:
tried this place for the first time and was disappointed...after reading about the yummy, flakey croissants i went and got one and it was bad. not even remotely close to croissants in paris...and i've had better croissants around sf also.

there was no flakey-ness, and a bit greasy on the fingers. i ate as much as i could, thinking somewhere in the middle of the croissant i'd be proven wrong, but i got through two-thirds and tossed the rest. i know it wasn't stale either - saw them take it right off the baking rack. oh wells.
author: Jill L.

description:
A real hidden gem! I was looking for a birthday cake for dear hubby and goggled around for suggestions and voila someone mentioned this little place in glen park.

I walked in expecting a huge bakery with array of items. Well, it is kind of a small place, more like an intimate coffee house . They don't have a huge and fancy menu of cakes but just a few - including the awesome chocolate cake that I ordered. I picked it up two days later and my husband loved it! No more safeway cakes for sure now!
Reasonably priced- 26 for a small cake and tasty ( not sugar loaded to kill)! Give this place a try if you live anywhere near Glen park.
author: Dee N.

description:
WOW!  I discovered this bakery at the Glen Park Farmers Market.  

Trust me on this:  get one of their fruit galettes.  Magic!
author: Patricia W.

description: Best brownie on earth, made with high quality French chocolate.We buy a half dozen and freeze them.
author: Bleep S.

description: This bakery has freshly made pastries which rock my socks off. Added bonus: Destination takes card unlike many Glen Park locations.
author: Johanna W.

description:
parking is difficult in this stretch of glen park...the place is also around the corner from all the Main Business in Glen Park.

everything looks great.  it smells great.  good atmosphere...nice customers that i can see as they sit around and drink coffee(felt like cheers for a moment as they looked at me like, who's the new guy?) i've lived near this place all my life but didn't notice it tucked away around the corner from all the main restaurants and business.

i had the crumb cake, which was slightly dry...i don't know if its because it had been around a while or if it was new.

i had a rasberry/chocolate tart which was very good.  kind of sweeter than i'm used to.  they had lots of other things too.

this is just my preliminary try and review.  i'll come back and try something i'm not used to having...and if its good that i want to come back for that...then i'll change my rating to at least 4 stars.

if they taste like, the go to, baked goods that i tried....then i'll leave it at 3.

in the meantime.  give it a try and let me know what You think.
author: Bing D.

description:
Driving round Glen Park, not a hood I know well.  See sign "LOCAL APPLE PIE". Looks like they're serious.
180 the car. Park at fire hydrant, run in.

Heart-stopping moment as I see The Pie, and she sees me. 

It's love.

"PIE! PIE! PIE!" I shout to the man, and point excitedly, hopping from one foot to the other like a crackhead with the DT's

"$18 sir."

".. PIE!!!" I wave $20 at him, grab pie+fork, and hotfoot it out the door, leap into getaway vehicle, and we zoomed off to a cheap motel room on Ocean beach for an afternoon of carnal pleasure.

* Best Apple Pie in the city * (or at least as good as the very best French-style Patisserie apple treat, but this is more home-style).

Big Chunky pieces of real Tasty Apple, hint of cinnamon, wonderful crust. 

Oh god it was good. I saved some till the next day and it was even better. I love this city.
author: Dr T.

description:
Destination Baking Company's fruit tartlets are the cutest tarts I've ever seen.  I especially love the Banana Tart; perfectly layered with whip cream, not overly creamly as other places seem to do.  I would like to see a bit more banana's in  the tart, but overall, I love coming here to for my fruit tarts.  

I hope to try some of their other pastries in the future .
author: Cass J.

description:
Destination is one of my absolute favorite places in San Francisco for baked goods.  WHo knew I could love a fruit danish?  But, theirs are so wonderful, with freshly made fruit fillings.  The icing on their pastries is fabulous.  They also make wonderful pies and tarts.

Round challahs for the New Year were terrific.

They are also exceptionally lovely people.  Joe, the owner, is very sweet, as is Deb, who works the counters regularly in the morning.  They just celebrated their 10 year anniversary.

I LOVE destination.
author: Julie C.

description:
Just one word: PIE.  I have been searching for 4 years for the ideal fruit pie in San Francisco and finally I found it. Addictive is an understatement. Perfect crust - flaky but not overly buttery or oily, fruit fillings have the perfect level of sweetness - (ie not too sweet ) - no fillers of any note - honestly, perfect.   I have not tasted one (pear cranberry, ollallieberry, apple, peach raspberry....) that wasn't a knockout. BTW they only make pies Thursday - Sunday.
OK - there is another related word: Galettes -Compared to the pies, a different, more buttery, sweeter crust; equally delicious fruit fillings - and these they make every day.
author: Stephen B.

description:
PDG - pretty dang good!

As I was leaving yoga class, the scent of cinnamon rolls just about roped me into the bakery.

After perusing the pastries, I decided on a sticky bun (with nuts). Not being a selfish person, I also picked up a croissant and a pain au chocolat for the husband and child. (When we all have pastries, it doesn't make me look like a piggy.)

The sticky bun was out of this world - the first sticky bun I've had where they used cardamom - yum! 

But the real star was the croissant and pain au chocolat. They're slightly crispy on the outside and rich, buttery and a bit dough-y on the inside. My husband, a Parisian (and self declared know-it-all on what a croissant should be like), and I decided that Destination's croissants are THE best this side of France.

Now, I'm trying to figure out how to make Destination Bakery a convenient stop on my way to work...
author: Kelly R.

description:
Let's start where I usually start at Destination, which is with the croissants. They are the best I've ever had, anywhere. I spent a week in Paris this year and didn't  find any croissants quite as good. And I looked. Joe's croissants are loaded with butter but manage not to be greasy. They have a very mildly sour taste, in a good way, the way very high quality butter like Strauss gives off a tiny bit of sourness. And they are crisp but not burnt. The plain croissants are particularly good. I have had dozens of them over the years and the quality has never varied.

No, they are not dense and bread-y, as another reviewer commented, albeit disparagingly. If you go around the corner to Pebbles Cafe, which carries products from Bay Bread, you can get this kind of bread-y croissant. It is vastly inferior to the Destination croissant in my opinion. It is unnuanced, unchallenging, and uninteresting, more or less just a roll and not really worthy of being called  croissant.

My partner usually starts with one of the cinnamon rolls, a sticky bun, or a bear claw. These are equally yummy - yeasty, buttery, and sweet without being cloying.

After lunch, I often drop in at Destination to get one of their small pastries. They are yummy, perfect with coffee, and not too large, very suitable for an afternoon snack without stuffing one's face. 

I think of San Francisco commercial pastry generally as a sad state of affairs, partly because the product is often so large and at the same time so tasteless. Eating a chocolate chip cookie can be like eating an entire stick of butter. Scones can be big enough to feed a family of four. Not at Destination - smaller sized things, but very high quality, and that's just how I like it. The fruits used in tarts there are especially good - very high quality apricots and strawberries. I have spoken with the owner about this and he has told me that he sources much of his produce from local organic farms. I am not an ideologue when it comes to local produce and sustainability issues, but trust my taste buds, and Destination has given them some very nice moments.

Cakes are very good, too. A few years ago, we ordered our wedding cake from this bakery. It was beautiful, and unbelievably tasty. 

Destination is far and away my favorite bakery in San Francisco. How it has escaped a mention in Patricia Unterman's San Francisco Food Lover's Guide for all these years is just beyond me. 

I so want to love Tartine - the place is beautiful, and so is their product, and it's such a cool scene, and it's closer to where I live. But every time I go there, I think to myself "this just doesn't taste as good as Destination." Not even close, really.
author: David G.

description:
I've been going to this bakery since it was Creighton's.  Lately everytime I go to get something they are sold out. The owner told me that next time I wanted a cake or pie I should order one at least two days in advance.  OK.   So I went in to order a pie and they told me that I couldn't order a pie in advance.  I offered to pay for it up front.  They still said no, that I just had to show up and hope for the best. The pie isn't that good that I'm going to schedule my day around scoring a pie.

Could someone remind them that they are a bakery ?  Quick review of the business model.  People come in and give them money and they give people baked goods.
author: Ava M.

description:
baguette still warm from the oven which i purchased at the cheese boutique down the block (instead of from the bakery) was crusty and full of nice flavor. the bakery itself is a little worn and cramp but serves a seriously dark rich coffee and yummy pastries. 
here is a quick list of goodies I tasted (with some help):
-a moon pie (two chocolate cookies sandwiched with a creamy non marshmallow white stuffing), - my foodie-in-training little one commented to me that marshmallow stuffing would have been a better choice. i agree but it was still tasty. 
-a wonderfully caramelized sticky bun to die for.  I would get this again!
-a bread pudding that lacked a discern-able sweet to spice profile. 
-a very  average banana bread with walnuts.
-a nicely flavored Gruyere cheese twist
I definitely will be back for quality french baguettes and more of those sticky buns.
author: Jeff W.

description:
I'm not sure if I came too early or came too late (10 am), but for some reason, it didn't seem like they had much product.  They must bake really small batches or they're immensely popular (or both).  It wasn't crowded at the time but maybe everyone knows to come early.  

I had a hard time identifying the croissants because they didn't look like the traditional croissants that I'm used to and they don't label their goods.  They were dark brown and not as fluffy.  Honestly, they looked more like crescents.  I was skeptical but I tried the chocolate croissant and though it wasn't the prettiest it was excellent.  It's flaky on the outside and denser than usual.  Definitely made with plenty of butter.  It needed more chocolate but that's a minor flaw.  

They only had two cupcakes left: vanilla cake with chocolate frosting.  This was my first time receiving a cold cupcake (refrigerated) and I didn't like that aspect too much.  The cake was undeniably dry.  The frosting was hard (well it was refrigerated) but I will say that it tasted like they used good chocolate.  I liked the chocolate non-pareil they put on top.  But I don't think cupcakes are their forte.  

I sampled a white bread that was very good - chewy crust, tender inside.   They also serve up espresso drinks.
author: Lolia S.

description:
Open early and very, very good.

My favorites include:
fruit gallettes (i.e. pear and cranberry), bear claws, almond croissants, Italian coffee cake, fruit Danish, cookies
author: J.Fred D.

description:
I've been making this bakery a destination for many years.  Used to come here weekend mornings with my dog and sit outside on the benches.  It was a great way to start a weekend.
My favorites start with the baguettes, which are dense, sweet and buttery with just enough crunch. Fantastic for sandwiches.
Don't leave without tasting the apricot scones - these are so good. The pies I have had here range from scrumptious to heavenly.  Glen Park is lucky to have such a talented baker.
author: Gary F.

description: I came here the day I failed my driving test, but the muffin was still very good.  The staff seems to be very regular and are very nice to the customers.  I once got cupcakes here for a party and they were standard and not super expensive.  I don't know why I don't come here more often because it's right near my house and on my way to work.
author: Julia D.

description:
Two dollars and fifty cents for a moderate sized chocolate croissant seemed a bit steep given the ~$2 ones I usually get around the FiDi. One bite was all I needed to appreciate the perfectly proportioned chocolate oozing between its light, flaky pastry blanket, tasting fresh off the baking pan. 

What a shame I didn't visit this hidden gem more often in my old 'hood. I'll definitely be back for more...
author: Sara N.

description:
My boyfriend and I stopped at Destination Baking Company for the first time for a late breakfast pastry & coffee.

Their coffee is yummy and we shared a sticky bun of some sort, with nuts, that I couldn't seem to find anything to complain about.  

We were tempted by their tartlets and shared a banana cream one with an almond crust - uber delicious! 

I liked the atmosphere and how happy all of the workers were - seems like a labor of love!

We really liked this place - and we'll come again for sure.
author: Roxanne B.

description: I had only the quiche and it was delicious. I live in the East Bay and am looking for a reason to visit again. The crust  to the pie was great and the egg mixture was moist and not done perfectly. What I really had my eye on was the bread pudding! I resisted and you know how it goes...things you resist tend to persist!! Haven't stopped thinking about it.
author: Mary P.

description:
Having lived pretty close to Glen Park for many years, I had never explored beyond the BART station itself.  I didn't know that there is a beautiful valley with a nice trail between SOTA (what used to be Macteer high school) and Glen Park station.  I also didn't know there are a dozen adorable shops on Chenery.  

Following my cousin's advice, we walked a bit on Chenery looking for THE bakery.  No wonder she forgot the name: there are no huge, visible signs outside.  

The inside is clean.  Actually, a little too clean.  Apparently we were there too late (around 3 or 4ish on a weekend), and most things seem to be sold out already. 

So we bought a tart and a bread pudding.  My husband said the tart was okay, but the bread pudding we shared was quite good.  Egg-y, buttery, sugary on top, and has raisins.  Reminds me of nice bread puddings served in restaurants.  Except the portion is pretty big, about 4" x 4".
author: Candice B.

description: Every neighborhood's gotta have a bakery, and Glen Park is no exception.  The food doesn't disappoint here, so if you live nearby, a morning walk to this bakery could easily become a weekend ritual.  Also seems like a great place to run into your friends.  But if, like me, you don't live in Glen Park, there's no particular reason to make the trip.
author: Wes M.

description:
After reading all of the glowing reviews, I really, truly wanted to love Destination. I want to be a cool Glen Parker and fit in with the hip, up and coming neighborhood. 

But I can't.

There's another bakery out there (rhymes with sateen) that has totally ruined Destination for me.   

I ordered a lot because I didn't want to miss out on ANYTHING. 

Let's begin with the tartlets:

I had the chocolate, mazarin (raspberry/almond), and banana cream. I prefer a flaky crust over the crumbly one that is offered at Destination. The fillings are simple, but unimaginative. Chocolate too rich, raspberry too sweet, and banana cream just left me wanting something more.

On to the cakes:

It's true that they keep their cakes in the refrigerator. I suspect that this is necessary because it's like 80 degrees in there. The ovens are literally 10 feet away from the cash register. 

The cold cakes (cupcake, carrot cake, moon pie) make the frostings hard, so I waited for them to come to room temperature before enjoying them. The cupcake was yellow bottom with chocolate top. My favorite combination of ALL TIME. To my dismay, the cake is super dry! Like sawdust topped with chocolate ganache. :( Majorly unpleasant. Cupcakes, in my opinion, should be frosted with frosting and not ganache.The carrot cake was okay. But totally like something I make. Not something that I would pay for.  With so many glowing reviews of the moon pie, I was saddened with the fatty, tasteless confection that I purchased.

The shining star was the chocolate croissant! I love the small shape and the sprinkle of salt on top. Terribly chic! Nice and flaky and just the right amount of chocolate. 

I threw in a loaf of plain challah at the last moment. I like how they don't over bake it. I like my challah a little pale. After I dry it out, I'm going to make Sateen's bread pudding with it tonight. :D 

One last note about pricing. While the Destination banana cream tartlet is a mere $2.50, there really isn't anything in there besides banana-flavored custard and cream. Sateen's banana cream tart has chocolate, caramel, sliced bananas, custard, and cream for about $5. And about 10 times the size of the tartlet! I know where to get more bang for my buck!
author: Jacquee P.

description:
I stopped by Destination Baking Co. at 6:40 am. The neighborhood is quiet at that time and there are places to park. 

There were numerous hot, fragrant baked items just coming out of the ovens... I chose four pastries-- a chocolate croissant, a plain croissant, a cherry Danish, and a giant cinnamon raisin bun. I gave the plain croissant and cinnamon bun to co-workers and didn't get to taste them, but another co-worker and I shared the chocolate croissant and cherry Danish. Both were still warm, and made of flaky, crispy, chewy, melt-in-your mouth dough... I didn't even know a bread item could be all those things at once until I tried Destination Baking Co's treats! 

The cherry filling of the cherry Danish was tart and delicious and obviously made from real cherries (they probably don't have this Danish in winter, but maybe they'll have apple then). The chocolate croissant has just the right amount of complex, dark chocolate filling, with some coarse sugar sprinkled on the top of the bread. it could definitely cause a chocolate croissant addiction.

All four pastries together were $9. The cinnamon bun is enormous and definitely enough for two people to share, and the bakery makes all their dough fresh (many bakeries have freshly baked pastries, but most are made with frozen dough, frozen cinnamon rolls, etc). They use organic ingredients when possible, so I think the pastries are a good deal!
author: Dani Y.

description:
I cannot comment on the offerings from the rack, but we ordered our wedding cake from Destination and could not have been more pleased.

We wanted a very simple cake without a lot of embellishment.  We had our florist add greens and flowers to the simple cake so that it fit with the rest of our decor.  We were more concerned about taste and it was delicious.

Everyone one commented on how great it was.  One co-worker cursed me for brining the leftovers to the office.  

And it was literally half the price of other alternatives we considered.

Our only complaint was that we had to come in twice, once to discuss options and once for the tasting.  A well developed website could have perhaps saved us the first visit.  The owner, Joe, says it is being developed.  In the end though we were glad to meet with Joe and his personal participation was one of the reasons we selected destination.
author: Gill S.

description:
my man Ross told me about the chocolate croissants that were so good you have to order two of them.  Because while your eating the first one in the joint before you even pay for it while they make your drink, you have to eat another one when you get home, and you must get one to go.

So I went and lets just say I will never eat the chocolate croissants at starbucks or anywhere else for that matter ... once you get done with half of one you really hope there is another one in the bag

omfg 

the staff is nice and they take credit card, parking is so-so so I would do a drive by order to-go, it has a few spots to sit but its a lil tight.

love it!
author: Marcus B.

description:
I was bubbly with excitement about this bakery.... and they had my ultimate cupcake - yellow cake w/ chocolate frosting (unlike my fave nearby Noe Valley Bakery).  Had I finally found my cupcake mecca?  But as I bit into the cupcake, it was so.....DRY.....

I'm quite disappointed. *sigh*.  So much promise, and yet such a letdown.
author: Jane A.

description: Joe the baker is the real thing.  I've been a customer since his first day.  Destinations is and continues to be a big improvement over old Creighton's that was in the same location previously.  The chocolate croissants are my favorite. Joe and his crew bake great pies for Thanksgiving.   And they always have good bakery coffee.
author: James D.

description:
Overrated (IMHO).  Just whatever.  I like the food and the atmosphere at Tartine better.  There's too much sugar in everything... and I like sweet.  

Last week, I overheard one of the bakers arguing with a neighbor (?) on the phone, something about the noise or music being too loud.  I have to agree with the neighbor... the music was annoyingly loud inside.  I'm just glad I don't live upstairs or next door.
author: Derek S.

description:
I can't speak to cakes, croissants, sticky buns, or cinammon rolls.  I don't eat 'em.

But I *can* speak to pie.  I love pie.  I adore pie.  Who cares about cake or cookies or ice cream when there's pie?  Really.

So if you want some damn good pie with flaky (but not greasy) crust, fresh homemade filling (just the right amount, too), perfectly spiced, baked, and porportioned, your destination is Destination.  Nothing is too sweet or too tart.  It's all...just right. Mmmm.... pie.

p.s.: Not in the mood for pie?  Get their tarts!  Like a mini pie but with a cookie crust.  And so many flavors: lemon, lime, raspberry, apple, pecan, chocolate...mmmm.... tarts.
author: Susannah M.

description:
Needed to stave off hunger before class so I headed here for a caffeine fix and a little something to nosh on. Cute little corner coffee house with a few tables to sit at wit big windows to let the beautiful sun shine in. The place was filled with the smell of fresh bread and cookies right out of the oven. I scanned the two display cases and spotted potatoes samosa empanadas....oh yea! 

The mocha latte was like any other mocha latte, no big whoop there. The potaote samosa empanada tasted like an actual potatoe samosa (spices, peas and potatoes) but instead of the flaky philo crust it was that soft doughy shell. The guy at the counter told me that I HAD to try their bread pudding and so he slipped a piece in my bag. Boy was he right! That bread pudding was damn good! Not too much raisins but enough so that I had one in each bite. $6 for my breakfast and caffeine fix...sweet!
author: Lola L.

description:
I would love to talk about the fine assortment of baked goods featured at Destination, however this place was CLEANED OUT by the time we rolled in here at 10:30 Saturday morning. I still got the gist of it though. 

I hadn't had breakie yet so I wasn't looking for something too sweet anyway. I opted for the vegetable samosa which even though it was not authentic as it was more a baked good than an Indian staple, it was delicious. 

None-the-less, it hit the spot and I was pleased to have had the opportunity to visit and support such a fine and wholesome establishment.
author: alexa c.

description: Don't tell customers you have pies to sell when you don't!  Apparently, you need to preorder ahead of time.  Please be considerate of people's time and gas!!!!
author: Maria T.

description:
I have been 'shopping' around for a favorite bakery these days. You know, a place to get that extra buttery perfectly flakey croissant and a cup of coffee to start one's day? I think I've found it. I've  been to this place a handful of times, and I have never been disappointed. I usually get their croissants, because they are the closest to the ones I remember in Paris. I also picked up their baguette, hoping to find a place that can make those baguettes that are ubiquitous in France but impossible to find in the US, even in foodie San Francisco. Well, their baguette isn't it, either, but not bad! I got mine still warm from the oven. It was sour dough and I am afraid I am not a fan of sour dough (I know, sacrilege!), but theirs was yummy and fresh. The coffee was also nice and I appreciate how they put out soy milk for those of us who prefer it. I also appreciate that they don't charge extra for a 'splash' of soy, too.

The only down side is that they are a  bit out of the way, but maybe that is a good thing for those who live nearby.
author: 和子

description:
I don't drink coffee and I'm not much on sweats and deserts...

I don't know what it is with the sticky buns at this place, but I turn into a sugar craving maniac whenever I happen anywhere in the vicinity. I'm pretty sure they put crack in them....
author: Robin S.

description: Coffee Cake and double mocha, good in my book. too bad it closes at 6:30, love the way the sunlight hits the table.
author: Tiff W.

description:
I used to stop here all the time on my way to the BART station when I had to go there on my way to work.  They open at 6:30, and I'd stop by around 6:45, just as the cinnamon rolls were coming out of the oven.  I'd always get a cinnamon roll and a milk and eat it on the way to work.  Delicious.

Unfortunately, I don't go that way to work anymore.  I have gone to Destination a few times since then, but it was later in the day.  I have to say, the cinnamon roll is not nearly as good when it's not ultra-fresh.  The cinnamon rolls I've gotten in the afternoon are fairly disappointing.  Most of the rest of their stuff that I've tried is so-so, such as their cupcakes.

So if you can go when they first open, do so.  Otherwise, go at your own risk.
author: Chad H.

description: just when I thought strawberry rhubarb was so last decade, I had to eat here...damn it.  Now I'm in love again.  Can you guys get a Weight Watchers punch card?  I'm going to need it...
author: Matt V.

description: Talk about a well-kept secret!  I can't believe how good this bakery is and how little traffic I see in here.  I'm a big fan of amazingly good French baguettes, and Destination's are some of the best I've found so far in this country.  Do yourself a favor and have one of the chocolate tarts, too - the little piece of gold foil gives it a fancy touch, but there's nothing wrong with munching one of these delectable cups of goodness while you walk around Glen Park Village.  I feel very lucky to live near this place.
author: Michael I.

description: So their selection is small, but everything is fresh, especially their fruit tartlets. $2.75 each. Bet you can't eat just one!
author: Jonas T.

description:
Love the scones and cookies, the pain au chocolat is excellent as well.  The bread is pretty good though can be hit or miss.  I thoroughly enjoyed the quiche both times I got it, and the empenadas are good if not a little bland.  

Got a Pecan pie for Thanksgiving from them and albeit pricey, it was excellent.
author: David T.

description: Carrot cake was moist and topping was delish.  Just a quick stop here so can't give a full review.  Cute location nice local feel.
author: April M.

description:
I live on the other side of town, and drive all the way over to destination bakery just to have some of the city's best pastries.

(with high gas, I might cut down on that)

But it's good, and the attitude of the people there and the owner Joe is really positive
Plus, the cinammon (sic) rolls and cupcakes, plus tarts, are really, really good
author: Kevin R.

description:
I thought I was basically done with active Yelp!ing.  But I still log on everyday and read reviews from my homies and stalkees (aka friends and favourites, respectively).  And today, I was hit with this feeling of..  "Oh sigh.  I wish I had reviews to write.  I wish my Yelp page weren't so pathetic-looking.  I wish I still felt something."  Then my cold, cold heart melted a little, and sitting there in the thaw, was my love for Destination Bakery.

And speaking of renewed loves:
I *just* saw John Mayer's VH1 show - "John Mayer has a TV Show" - despite its old news.  Yeah, I live in a hole, where we only watch Deal or No Deal and other manner of terrible things.  Anyway.  He's hilarious.  And I love (watching) him.

If only John Mayer worked at Destination.  I'd go everyday.  And I bet you their tip jar would be spilling over.  

But even though he doesn't work there, I still manage to make my way over there occasionally.  I've only tried: lemon tartlet, baguette, bread pudding.

Ok, so the lemon tartlet was just like any other tartlet.  And the baguette was a baguette.  But then again, my baguette palette is not awesome, but I generally just LOVE bread anyway.

But there are two reasons I keep coming back:
1) The bread pudding.  Despite the fact it has raisins (BLECH) and is a bit too sweet and maybe is not doughy enough...  I do Really like it.  And to be honest, I'm pretty sure I like it more than the Tartine bread pudding that I had only once.  It has this lovely, burnty sugar appeal on the surface bread peaks.  I also love that the flavour is tinged with buttery and vanilla-y goodness.  And it's a HUGE piece for a mere $2.75.

2) Part of the appeal also lies in that fact that it has such a corner bakery, neighbourhoody feel.  There are always a few people inside and/or outside, just chillin with a snack and a newspaper.  And even though it's not in my 'hood, it's still within walking distance.  Combine that with the homeyness, and I just cannot help but love this place.  It's my great weekend treat to make my way over and get a piece of bread pudding (lasts me two days since I discovered the concept of portion control).  I certainly deserve it after climbing the hill that is the end of Noe Street to Laidley (yeah, it doesn't sound that impressing, but my chest pains beg to differ.  Google Map:terrain that 'ness, ok?).

As added bonus: The pies at Mission Pie are baked here - anyplace that enables my pie consumption is delightening beyond comprehension.

I am determined to visit often enough and order the bread pudding each time, such that someday I can just roll in, give a knowing nod to the dude at the counter, and say "i'll have the us(ual)" (How does one spell that phonetically?  "yujje"?).  Yeah, that's right, I've got goals.

While we're on the topic of nothing in particular, here are few more tidbits of random trivia/my feelings:
-I am going to start eating my cereal with water.  Because milk is gross and I just need something to dilute the sugar in my Smart Start.
-My favourite Favourites are Peter M. and Keane L.
-Sugar crystals are not as soluble as salt crystals.
author: Jess M.

description:
I love their different fruit tarts with the crumbly, buttery crusts and the amazing fruit fillings.  This is definitely my favorite Glen Park destination!

On weekends they have delicious fruit pies also.  Think of those delicious little fruit tarts only in a much bigger size.  Oh my!
author: Sara A.

description: I called this morning and a guy told me their lots of apple pies. When I got here in less than 5 minutes they did not have any apple pies. What bad service. The lady behind the counter did not care and let me and my 2 daughters leave without even trying to help us. So we went the noe valley bakery and got great service and no waiting and got a apple pie.
author: Joel Y.

description:
3 recent discoveries:  

1.  gialina pizzeria (camer here after watching check please) 
2. after dinner at gialina - rediscovered cute lil glen park neighborhood after about 20 years (so close to work & the hood i grew up in, & i drive by a million times over the years) 
3.  destination bakery up the hill....

the bakery was about to close but was able to get a few goodies.

- disappointed with the $1.85 red velvet cupcake -- too dry & lacked flavor
- but extremely happy about their tartlets, which is what they're known for:
excellent shortbread crust on tarts, my favorite.
1.  banana cream tartlet -- w/ fresh slices of bananas, just the right amount of cream, balanced -- my fave!
2.  mazarin -- w/ almond (marzipan?) & topped w/raspberry (preserves/jam???) -- yum
both are excellent day time treats w/tea or coffee
3.  apple streusal (bought 2)-- 1st one i thought was waaayyy tooooo sweet especially for breakfast very 1st thing in the morning (& i sure can handle sugar), everything else about it was perfect -- the crust, the sliced apples, spices, the streusal crumb topping, the 2nd one i stole from my hub -- was really good, wasn't as sweet, actually now perfect, the way i like it ....not sure if its b/c its a completely different batch or just better time of day in the afternoon.

can't wait to go back for more tarts & try the other sweet goodies, but won't go back for cupcakes............
author: Cindi N.

description: 5 huge stars for destination!!! Just thinking about their tarts and carrot cake makes my mouth water.My favorite tarts are the lemon and bananas and now the new strawberry!the tart shells are done just right and the lemon has the perfect sweet to tart ratio yummy!!! I love the carrot cake oh geez I can go all day talking about this bakery but the carrot cake is so moist and the frosting is this delish melt in your mouth cream cheese frosting without the nuts which is a plus cause I hate !!! The BF had bread pudding and swears by it know he said the best in the city!!! The staff is so sweet! 5 dollars for my 2 tarts and worth every penny. Much better then tartines! And who doesn't love glen park!try destination I promise you will love it !!! Oh and the Dutch apple pie to die for!
author: Sabrina M.

description: I used to be pretty stoked on this place when I moved to Glen Park a couple years ago. They had really tasty pastries, although they seemed a bit expensive. Coffee was never a strong point there. But, the other day I got some croissants, and they seemed much too greasy. I can't say that I will be going back soon when there are so many other options...
author: sadie r.

description: Heaven!!! I love everything here, but the bread pudding is to die for. I didn't even know I liked bread pudding until somebody talked me into trying theirs. Excellent staff too.
author: R G.

description:
You can tell a lot of love goes into the goodies at Destination.  The apricot scone tasted like your mommy made it.  You should have seen the monstrous delights that were being sent out to various locales when I was there.  I also had the chicken empanada that was chock-full of cheese, chicken, corn, and cilantro.  The crust was soooo flaky!

Loved the ambiance as well.  You can tell it's a local establishment with dedicated customers.  I will definitely be back to stuff my face!

Workin' on my muffin top....
author: Paul D.

description: Great tartlets, so so chocolate croissant and definitely not a "destination."  Get everything 'to-go' b/c this is not a cute place to sit and enjoy the baked goods.  The whole bakery is open to the kitchen (which is fine) but it is a no frills place w/ no decor, nothing.  Definitely a solid bakery but nothing worth going out of your way for.
author: Barndi K.

description: OMG. This is the best pic crust ever. The peach pie sent me to a near orgasm.  I usually hate crust but this buttery and flaky piece of heaven makes one day dream of meadows, peach gardens and first love.
author: Margarita B.

description:
You need to come early to this bakery or else everything will be sold out.  I wanted to get the Crossiant but it was sold out by 10am.  All that was left was the cinnabon, pecan, tarlet strudels, and cupcake.  

I selected the chocolate frosting cupcake. It was simple.  $1.75?

I need to try more pasteries to decide but 3 stars for now.
author: Jboogie L.

description: I love this place! It's right down the road from us, and let me tell you, we've gained a few pounds because of it! Everything we've had from them has been really good and fresh. I have to recommend the moon pie..delicious!
author: Rose L.

description:
Actually, 3 and a 1/2 stars.  

My carrot cake was yummy.  It didn't have any raisons or walnuts and the frosting wasn't the BEST I've had on carrot cake.  But, it was still very tasty.

I was a little bummed that their lemon tarts aren't made with meyer lemons.  They use meyer lemons in a cake, why not use them in their tarts as well?  The tarts are more of a one person bakery item than a larger cake is.  I don't know, just my thoughts on that and that I'm also a HUUUGE fan of meyer lemons....
Plus, I don't want to have to purchase a full size cake just to enjoy the flavor of meyer lemons:)

I'm guessing the am time has more of a selection than the later part of the day.  I mean, since it is a bakery and all.  I could be wrong though....
author: Kat M.

description:
The BEST croissants, the BEST challah, etc, etc, etc!
Destination Baking company in the epitome of a great local small business and a fantastic reason to visit the small, but very friendly neighborhood of Glen Park.
OK, seriously, the best croissant in the city - melt in your mouth, crispy, flaky, chewy, and a perfect dark brown color...you can smell them from afar and there's nothing like it, unless you're in Paris. The chocolate version is sinful, and when paired with a cup of coffee, you'd swear Twin Peaks is the Eiffel Tower.
If you're looking for the best Challah bread, go to Destination on Fridays, and buy one...but think about buying two, because once you taste it, you wont be able to stop.
They also make sublime baguettes daily that are irresistible, not to mention fruit galettes, killer cinnamon buns, chewy chocolate chip cookies (with and without nuts) cupcakes, moon pies, and wonderful savory choices like empanadas!
The bakery's employees are the real thing - friendly, funny, and such a big part of the great feeling you get upon entering. 
It's a little gem of a place, and once you go, you'll be back, like all the Glen Park residents and other fans alike!
Oh, don't let me forget to mention the PIES! They are out of this world!!
author: Julia m.

description: I ordered a Mardi Gras King Cake from Destination. It was filled with cream cheese and was quite delicious. If you're missing the hometown version, this one is quite close to what you'll find in New Orleans. I'll suggest they supply the plastic baby, on the side if needed. The very nice baker there told that due to liability issues they bake a pecan into the cake instead of the baby. The pecan just does not have the same effect. Overall, I recommend their King Cakes highly. You'd better hurry though. Mardi Gras is tomorrow!
author: John D.

description: This is hands down the best croissant I have ever had in my life, and the best chocolate croissant as well.  I am forever ruined; no other will taste good in comparison.
author: Simona A.

description:
We were walking by and smelled the heavenly smell of pie, fresh out of the oven. Thus lured, we rushed inside and found a smiling man standing before a huge baker's rack of pies. "What kind of pies do you have?" I asked. "Apple, pumpkin, cherry, mincemeat--" I stopped him right there. "Did you say mincemeat?"  I demanded. No one ever has mincemeat. Sometimes I think I'm the only one in the world who likes mincemeat (with or without the meat). He answered: "Yes, mincemeat, but there's no meat in it." 

Five minutes later, we exited, me clutching a white box containing a mincemeat without the meat pie, hard pressed not to tear the box open and devour the pie right there on the street, with my hands. I managed to wait until after dinner on Thanksgiving day, and then while everyone else was having pumpkin (boooring) I topped my slightly warm slice of mince pie with a giant scoop Bi-rite's salted caramel ice cream and dug in. Readers, it was perfect. The crust was light and flaky. The filling was thick and sweetly sour, heavy with spice. The best mince pie I've had in a long time. I'm guessing the rest of their pies are good, too. But for now, I'm sticking to mince.

NOTE: It occurs to me that I should explain what mincemeat is, since many people hear the meat part of the word and they don't want to hear any more. Once upon a time mincemeat was a combination of apples, dried or candied fruit and spices, and finely chopped beef. Now days almost no one puts meat in the filling, even if they still call it mincemeat. In old timey days, the minced (finely chopped) ingredients  were then marinated in brandy for weeks and weeks before being baked into a pie. I doubt if there was alcohol in Destination Bakery's mincemeat pie, but it was full of minced apples, raisins, currants and spices. Think of mincemeat (minus the meat) as a heavily spiced apple and dried fruit pie. There--doesn't that sound delicious?
author: Lilla F.

description:
really cute bakery! stopped by for an after-lunch dessert before heading back to work and this place did not disappoint!

i ordered a red velvet cupcake to share for two and it was the perfect dessert.  not to heavy and perfectly moist,  the cream cheese frosting wasn't too cream-cheesey or heavy.  you don't even need milk to accompany it either, that's how light it is.

next time i'm in the area, i'll order the empanada or quiche, since it looks soo good!
author: Lucy W.

description: This is a great neighborhood bakery.  Try the lemon tarts and the apple tarts.  Amazing.  I stop by almost every day...
author: William T.

description: It's a shame that my dentist is in Glen Park, because I celebrate every cleaning with an after-appointment visit to Destination Baking Company.  Therein I purchase a sweet, delectable piece of pastry to deliciously refill all the newly cleaned gaps between my teeth.
author: Richard E.

description:
this place is so wonderful!

surprisingly I get the desserts as an afterthought - I am obsessed with the empanada. 

everything they have is incredibly flavorful and perfectly baked! I love the selection.  just enough so you know they do everything really well.  

it's kinda bad I live so close though...at least my walk home is up hill...
author: Niki B.

description: Destination Baking Company is DELICIOUS.  Everything I've ever tried there has been well worth the money and the staff is always friendly and helpful.  The coffee there is also VERY good.  I love the little nook they have to sit in, perfect for a breakfast for 2.  Destination Bakery is awesome!!
author: Rose C.

description:
There's nothing like waking up to the smell of freshly baked goods every morning! The bakery's treats are delicious, but I recommend going early (if you're heading there on a weekend) because the goodies sometimes get taken quickly. A few of my favorites include: danishes, sticky buns, and scones. The cakes and tarts are just as amazing, so this may not be a good place for the indecisive! 

Joe and his staff also make excellent holiday goods! All in all, this bakery is amazing and the staff is, too!
author: S W.

description: The best croissant you'll ever have. Ever!! Try the cholate or blueberry danish. You will not regret it.
author: Laura S.

description:
This bakery is yummy.  They make a large variety of goods:  Small tarts of many flavors, gorgeous rustic pies, a large variety of breakfast pastries, coffee cake, brownies, cupcakes, cookies, and bread.  You can order a cake with 48 hours notice.   The owner Joe and the rest of the staff couldn't be nicer.  Everything I've tried has been made with care and very tasty.

After 2 PM, their breakfast pastries are 2-for-1.

Less 'tude than Tartine, a much larger variety of yummy pastries and desserts than Liberty Bakery.
author: Kathy R.

description: It started off on a positive note when I got a  killer parking spot right across the street.  The tall blond woman at the counter's smile and attitude just set things even more on track. But when I sank my teeth into the flakey, butter edge of the apricot pastry I knew what I'd heard was TRUE!!! It was so delicious...I saw the sign that read "Ask us about our Birthday Cakes"...I think I have to check that out SOON!!!!
author: Jenn O.

description: This place will take you back to what a real pastry should taste like. Well, that's only if you are in your 30's or 40's. No, this is no Svenhards's Safeway bought pastries. Destination defies all competition when it comes to real fine ingredient filled products. There scones and bear claws are seriously bar none compared to anything you've ever tasted. Try the cherry or blueberry danish, or even the homemade bread. By far the best bakery in the whole bay area I think. Including arizmendi's on 9th which I do like, but Destination's crew are bionic when it comes to making honest to goodness tasty treats...!!!! Go there now and buy up the whole display from them so you can piss me off because it's all sold out..! Eat up.!
author: Sven S.

description: This is my "destination" for Challah - it's addictive - and I've tried the carrot cake and apple pie.  Have to try more - (but not too fast or I'll balloon out of my pants) - great food and sincere service.
author: Jeff H.

description: Oh man, this place, even before i lived in SF i knew about. Which is sad since not many do. To come here, it really HAS to be your destination! Everything made here is delicious. It's very small, but light. The people are very patient, they never get mad when i am trying to figure out what i want for $10 worth of pastries so i can use my ATM card :B
author: marcella r.

description:
Quite pricey.   Asked for a baguette at 9:20 AM...guy tells me they were 'just put in'...it will take about 30 minutes or so, "We have them around 9:30...duh, it's 9:20 now...you are a bakery...it's a baguette...shouldn't they be ready now?
Anyway, it's cute to shop in the neighborhood, but it's not too much to ask for a baguette at 9 AM in a bakery.
author: Vernon H.

description: Glen Park is on my "favorite neighborhoods" list and Destination Baking Company is why. Go there early and you get to see the bakers do their thing behind the counter. My favorites: Snickerdoodles, Lemon Tarts, Carrot Cakes, Vegetable Samosas, Chicken Empanadas, and Double Mocha Soy Lattes. If you like pies, Destination sends them out to Mission Pie (2901 Mission St.).
author: Leroid D.

description: Great place! Check them out after 2pm as they sell their goods half off! I loved this place when I lived near. Their cinnamon rolls, cookies, and strudels are phenomenal. Check em out.
author: J B.

description:
Best Latte in the city.  No crowds, unlike Tartine's.  

Cinnamon rolls okay, but the sheer silence on a Sunday morning was the best part.
author: Mel B.

description: I have to walk past this shop every single morning.  The smells that waft out of it are amazing.  Dangerous.  Like every morning.  It's torture.  I've had a nibble of their peach pie which was mind blowing (esp. since I'm not a pie person).  The croissant was uber buttery, to the point where it was too much.  I will say it was nice and flaky, it was a really yummy croissant, but not my fave due to the overly buttery-ness.  I did like the size of said croissant, tho, it was very normal and not all steroid-y like many I encounter.
author: Emily T.

description: On my way to the office in the morning, Destinations is liking having your own private bakery right there. The desserts are fresh and always tasty and the service is quick and friendly. I love sweets and this is the place to take care of that sweet tooth craving, as well as my coffee cake craving. Great place.
author: CR S.

description: I walk by destination on my "I'm trying to be healthy" walk from San Jose ave and ocean to my home in Noe Valley everyday, reminding myself, I don't need a pastry at 4 in the afternoon. I thought I could get away with not stopping in even though I knew everything was tasty, until a colleague brought in a box of delicious flaky butter pastries for another colleague's birthday, it is his favorite... and i caved. So delicious... chocolate croissant... so... I've begun taking the bus home. It was torture walking by. Like putting a gym next to a all you can eat buffet or something.
author: Niki M.

description: I dig this place but it's overpriced.  A decent selection of pastries (the scones are my fave), coffee and empenadas, but as i said the prices leave something to be desired.
author: Jamaal C.

description:
I this is definitely my favorite bakery in the city. It's a great place to feed my chocolate croissant addiction plus the little bundt cakes, the cupcakes, and the sticky buns are pretty good too. My mom swears by their plain croissants and their pecan pies which she orders for thanksgiving.

Also kudos to all the people there for taking my order for a red velvet cake and finishing within 24 hours so I would have something to take to our holiday party at work. By everyone's standards it was delicious and it saved the day for desserts.
author: Jessica B.

description: Really nice staff and outstanding moon pies. I'm not a fan of their savory items.
author: Angela K.

description: fantastic warm treats, warm people and a great owner JOE! No pastry shop is better in this city, they bake the food right in front of you and Joe is also a good person, started a high school pie backing dealeeeooohhh in the Mission. My mother, daughter and I have gone here for over ten years.
author: Karen S.

description: Must...resisit...baked goods. Actually, not that difficult for me, but that's not because DB's stuff isn't good -- I just don't have that much of a sweet tooth. My partner likes the sticky rolls, though, and that's how I know they're good, since I always need to steal a bite or two. If nothing else, I love to walk by with my pup and inhale the yummy smells.
author: Tara M.

description: Went back this morning for an apricot scone. (btw the croissants in the display case still looked overcooked, and there were big grease stains on the paper underneath....) The scone was good. nice crunchy crust, light and soft on the inside, and not overly sweet. I'm upgrading Destination to 3 stars, but avoid the croissant!
author: R Y.

description:
This is the best challah I have had in the U.S. 

I only wish they made rye bread!
author: Sarah C.

description: I  love Destination.  When I was knocked up I must have eaten 20 of their apple pies.  My partner eats a yellow cupcake with intensely dark chocolate frosting, daily.  I love the carrot cake.  And if you're a banana cream pie fan (and even if you're not), Destination's is a must-try.  Kind of chewy whole wheat crust, perfect custard-- not too sweet, excellent texture-- plenty of banana.  Yum-E, I tell you.  The only reason I don't give it five stars is that the coffee is only ok.
author: Chris P.

description: This place used to taunt me on my runs from Now Valley to Glen Park.  Nothing like the smell of fresh baked yumminess to make you want to give up the whole exercise thing and gorge on pastries.  Well, now I live in the GP, so I am at DBC almost every day.  Their scones are the best!  I highly recommend the apricot or the currant.  Plus, the vanilla lattes and mochas are not too shabby.  Rock on Destination Baking Company!
author: Melissa G.

description: We go every weekend - I'm sticky buns with nuts, my friend w/o nuts and our daughter is a fanatic about the cheesy sticks. People are helpful and friendly, atmosphere is warm and welcoming - the espresso drinks are good...oh and the quiche!
author: Matthew S.

description: My favorite Mother's Day breakfast is croissants, so my family has over the years tried bringing me the croissants from many locations. We have finally stopped searching: These are my favorite - insanely buttery, crunchy on the outside and flaky throughout, peeling away in scrumptious fattening layers. No additional buttering needed.
author: katherine S.

description: my search for the best chocolate croissant is an ongoing continuum of yelping and driving to random spots. their chocolate croissant didn't look that appealing and i decided that i was going to save myself the calories and try it but probably not like it and give the rest away. but once i took a bite of it i couldn't stop. it wasn't because the chocolate was amazing or perfectly evenly distributed amongst the bread, because it wasn't. but it was SO buttery good that i had no choice but to consume it in it's entirety. happy tummy!
author: Regina C.

description: Hidden away on Chenery Street, this bakery has some of the best scones and tarts. Like any other junkie, I've had to change my route, take the bus and impose a restraining order on myself so that I don't give in to the Italian coffee cake. It's rich, buttery taste with just the right amount of sweetness still calls out to me. I may have to move away.
author: Arlene C.

description: Not a super big bakery, but what it lacks in quantity, it more than makes up in quality.  I like the moon pies and the Italian coffee cakes.  Uhmm, moist cake with real fruits, not candied fruit, mind you.  The carrot cakes are my daughter's favorite, she loves the frosting.  The chocolate tarts are very, very indulgent.  I would advise parking a bit far away, to work off all the goodies that are hard to resist tasting.
author: brenda b.

description:
Destination Baking Co. is worth the trek to Glen Park (not that Glen Park isn't great all on its own). You can smell the warm aromas tempting you from around the corner, and it is near impossible to resist.
Quaint and simple inside, the bakery has limited daily offerings, and what they do offer is a little slice of heaven. I got a Banana Cream Pie tart, PERFECTION! Seriously, I ate it w/ my girl "the up & coming pastry chef", and she couldn't find a single flaw, or possible room for improvement. I bought a moonpie for my boyfriend, he loved it, ate the crumbs like a caveman. My friend purchased a simple chocolate cupcake, great density and flavor, iced w/ ganache for an extra something special. 
If you feel like taking a moment out of your hectic life and treating yourself, I cannot think of a better way. Cheaper than a day at the spa, with the same feeling of satisfaction. 
4 stars are only temporary, b.c I need to go back and try more, but I can tell this is a five-star locale.
author: Nikka B.

description: Great little bakery hidden in Glen Park.  The chocolate croissant is amazing!  It's flaky, chocolaty, and oh so buttery!  The apple strudel tart is another winner.
author: Funk G.

description: I hope I don't regret writing this review.  I feel like I'm giving away a very well kept secret.  Fresh, fabulous baguettes every day, wonderful fruit tarts - a big hit if you're asked to bring dessert.  Everything is exceptional and is made right there.
author: Carolyn S.

description: Oh, how I love the sticky buns here. Available with or without nuts, they're a hunk of caramel-y goodness. If only my less-than-girlish figure could afford to eat more of them. They also have a pecan cake that's delish.
author: joanna p.

description: Chocolate chip cookies were absolutely heavenly. Browned on the outside and gooey on the inside. I will travel to Glen Park for these again.
author: Missy M.

description: The fresh apple pies are to die for.  Yum.  Also had a slice of a strawberry jam/preserve dessert (sorry, don't know the name) with a crisscross crust on top which was equally as good.  Will update as I try more.
author: Sue H.

description: We love this local bakery - so nice to have one in our neighborhood. Nice people and amazing pastries. Chocolate croissant and the pecan coffee cake are killer. Nice quiches and other items for lunch as well.
author: Brian M.

description: This place does prepare and serve fine quality bakery goods.  I was also impressed with their program where they help inner city youth learn how to bake.  Its a joint effort program with 25th Street Pies.  A community involved bakery, how cool can you get.
author: sidney b.

description: Fantastic cheese/fruit danish, scones hitting just the right balance of sweet/savory (in either kind even), serve yourself coffee to go that always gets me to my shrink on time, great locale affter trekking the dog through Glen Park Canyon. It really is a nice place to sit OR easy to do a driveby and grab what you need. Everyone is so nice there too. I just love Destinations.
author: Julia W.

description: Serving some of the best pastry treats and desserts by friendly people who seem to like what they do.  The added treat of watching the production process is extra delicious.  If you like sticky buns and cinnamon rolls (your choice with or without raisins), check it out.  You can get the simple to fancy (edible gold leaf) treats from this treasure found in the charming Glen Park village.
author: michael c.

description: For the biggest selection you gotta get there before 9am- the Mazarin tartletts (with almond and raspberry jam) are hella addictive- god- I'm craving them now just thinking about it.  I'm surprised someone got a pie there cos usually all the pies go to Mission Pies.  The owner is part owner of Mission Pies and I heard Mission Pies are building their own kitchen right now so soon they'll be baking all the pies and Destination won't have to anymore, so I hope that means pies can now be baked for Destination Baking- I love Glen Park and a cute little French Bistro just opened called P'tite Laurent (Laurent from Clementine) but that's another story!!
author: Monique G.

description: Cute little bakery at a street corner on Chenery.  The best danishes I have ever tried.  Their other sweets are equally delectable, try the chocolate chip cookies, the little tartlets, croissants.  They have a case of discount (day old perhaps?)  pastries that are a great deal also.
author: Naresh R.

description: Greasy, heavy bakery goods that make Safeway look delicious.
author: M K.

description: Although I know the baker/owner by virtue of being a long time customer, we don't hang out or anything. He is just a friendly guy who says hi to all when they come in. Today I went there for my monthly fix of croissant, and found that he was also carrying for a limited time, slices of apricot crostata. OOOOHHH, they make their own jam. So yummy. Also they are now making small quiches, which makes me a happy camper as I bought one to take for my lunch tomorrow. Best bakery in town, high quality ingredients and amazingly clean. I know my stuff because I spent 25 years in the restaurant business and I know clean when I see it.
author: Lisa B.

description: My three year and I go here for the tarts and sticky buns - both delicious!  Our favorite tart is the raspberry.  They have kids' books and bright picture windows with cushions that make it homey and nice, and the staff is very cordial and go out of their way to make you feel taken care of.  Very rich, so we only go once in a while, but it is a really wonderful little bakery with delicious smells always wafting from it.
author: M D.

description: This is a real neighborhood bakery. Very small, with a few tables, all window seats. The owner and staff are lovely. The place is spotless and the kitchen is right in front of you. You can watch them work. The food is divine. I have searched for perfect croissants in the Bay Area for years. I think I've found them at Destination. They have the right balance of butter, salt and sugar, with a crispy crust and light inside. The pies and muffins are terrific as well. While I haven't tried everything, everything I've tried has been great!
author: Sherrry G.

description: 5 stars for the Pecan coffee cake. Wow. I've had three bites now and needed to pause to share how yummy this pretty, swirly, moist, rich, crumbly, nutty cake tastes. I am really happy I picked it.
author: Jennifer F.

description: mmmmm... this place is the best when you want a sticky bun to crawl back into bed with and share with your honey on a Sunday morning!
author: Wendy G.

description: I love baked goods, both low-end and fancy, and I just haven't been wowed by anything I've eaten here.
author: Peter L.

description: Mmmm... Pastries!  Destination is such a nice little bakery with great sweets in the morning.  The Glen Park neighborhood would not be complete without it.  Plus, Deborah is one of the sweetest ladies I've ever met.  I love to stop by whenever I find the time.
author: Hao K.

description: I'm French, so I'm picky about my bakery. And this little hidden bakery is one of the best I know in SF. The plain and chocolate croissants are on par with those of 'La boulange de Cole' and 'La boulange de Polk'.  But this bakery is just a few minutes away! Our friends (just as picky as me) all asked us where these little puff pastry marvels were coming from. Definitely strongly recommend it.
author: Jordan L.

description: I have been a customer of this little bakery for years. I judge a bakery by its bread and croissants-plain croissants. DBC is number one in the city and I have tried many- including Tartines which is very good but doesn't have the flavor and texture of something that was made with love, not like DBC. They also make some absolutely fabulous pies, perfect crusts, smell to die for, taste like heaven. Coffee, quite good. Its more than that though, the owner is a man who loves what he is doing, and is the friendliest guy. He always make time to chat. Its human and warm, inviting, sunny and sleepy, like Glen Park! I love DBC, not only for the quality of its goods, but the quality of its people.
author: Lisa B.
